The Supreme Court pointed out that the law of preventive detention is harsh to the person detained and, therefore, it must be strictly construed. The right of the detenu to make a representation against his detention flows from Art. 22(5). The representation is to be made to the authority having power to rescind or revoke the decision. Under S. 11 of the COFEPOSA read with S. 21of the General Clauses Act, three authorities are empowered to revoke a detention order,viz., the officer making the order, the State Government if the detaining officer is a State official and the Central Government. The Court has ruled that the action of the Page 1325 detaining authority in not taking out copies of the detenu's representation, and sending the same to the Central Government was not reasonable. A person in preventive detention suffers from certain handicaps. If he makes a request to forward copies of his representation to the State and Central Governments, "it would be a denial of his right to represent to the Central Government if the detaining authority as well as the State Government refuse to accede to his request and omit to forward his representation to the Central Government for consideration". The Court failed to understand "why such a technical and rigid view" is taken by the authority in the matter of personal liberty when a person is kept in preventive detention.30 The detenu sent his representation to the advisory board. The board considered the representation and sent its opinion to the Central Government. Thereafter the government confirmed the order, but did not consider the detenu's representation. Thus, there was no independent consideration of the detenu's representation by the government at any time. The Court has ruled in Gracy v. State of Kerala, 31 that there has been breach of the detenu's right under Art. 22(5). The obligation of the government to consider the representation is different, and in addition to the obligation of the board to consider the same. The detenu's right to have the representation considered by the government under Art. 22(5) is independent of the consideration of the detenu's case and his representation by the advisory board. Art. 22(5) casts a dual obligation on the detaining authority viz.: (i) to communicate the grounds of detention to the detenu at the earliest; (ii) to afford him the earliest opportunity of making a representation against the detention order which implies the duty to consider and decide the representation when made, as soon as possible. Although an infraction of the detenu's right to make a representation and its disposal by the authorities does not vitiate an order of detention passed by the detaining authority, it renders the continued detention illegal.32 (d) ADVISORY BOARD Another safeguard is provided by Art. 22(4) to a detenu under preventive detention. Under Art. 22(4)(a), preventive detention for over three months is possible only when an advisory board holds that, in its opinion, there is sufficient cause for such detention. The board must report before the expiry of three months. If the report is not made within three months of the date of detention, the detention would become illegal.33 The board is to consist of persons who are, or have been, or are qualified to act as the High Court Judges. For preventive detention up to three months, no reference to such a board is necessary. Under Art. 22(7)(c), Parliament is authorised to prescribe the procedure to be followed by an advisory board. From the tenor of Art. 22(4)(a), it is clear that a law of preventive detention may provide for detention up to three months without the safeguard of an advisory board. The 44th Constitutional Amendment enacted by Parliament in 1978,34 amended Arts.

to (7) so as to introduce therein a few more safeguards for the detenu as follows: (a) the maximum period for which a person may be detained without obtaining the opinion of the advisory board has been reduced from 3 to 2 months; (b) no person is to be kept in detention beyond two months unless the advisory board reports that in its opinion there is sufficient cause for such detention; (c) an advisory board is to consist of a chairman and not less than two other members; (d) the chairman of the board has to be a serving judge of the appropriate High Court and the other members may be serving or retired High Court Judges; (e) the board is to be constitutied in accordance with the recommendations of the Chief Justice of the appropriate High Court; (f) no person is to be kept in preventive detention beyond the maximum period prescribed by any law made by Parliament. The reason for making the above changes in the composition of the advisory board is to make the board Page 1326 independent of the executive so that it may look into a case of preventive detention objectively. But these constitutional amendments have not yet been effectuated and Arts. 22(4) to (7) still continue to be as they were before the 44th Amendment. (e) CONFIRMATION OF THE DETENTION ORDER From the wordings of Art. 22(4), the Supreme Court has spelled out the rule that not only the advisory board should report within three months of the date of detention order that, in its opinion, there is sufficient cause for the detention of the detenu, but also the government should itself confirm and extend the period of detention (beyond three months) within the three months time-limit. Failure on the part of the government to do so will render the detention invalid as soon as three months elapse and any subsequent action by the government cannot have the effect of extending the period of detention beyond three months. While confirming the order of detention, the government has not only to peruse the report of the advisory board, but apply its mind to the material on record.35 It is also necessary that the order of confirmation be in writing and be communicated to the detenu. The detenu whose freedom is in jeopardy is entitled to know the result of his representation. But lack of communication to him is merely an irregularity and it does not invalidate an otherwise valid detention.36 (f) PARLIAMENT'S POWER TO DISPENSE WITH ADVISORY BOARDS Under Art. 22(7)(a), Parliament may by law prescribe "the circumstances under which, and the class or classes of cases in which, a person may be detained for a period longer than three months" without referring his case to an advisory board under Art. 22(4)(a). The interpretation of this clause has caused some difficulty. In Gopalan, the Supreme Court held by majority that the word and between 'circumstances' and 'class' in this clause was used not conjunctively but disjunctively (i.e. it meant 'or', not 'and'). Therefore, it was not obligatory on Parliament to lay down both the 'circumstances' and 'classes', but could lay down either 'circumstances' or 'classes', of cases in which a person could be detained for more than three months without referring his case to an advisory board. But the Supreme Court overruled this view in Sambhu Nath Sarkar v. State of West Bengal .37 There s. 17A of MISA38 narrated five of the six heads mentioned in the Constitution39 for which a law of preventive detention could be made as the circumstances in which reference to an advisory board was not necessary. The Court declared the section unconstitutional. It treated Art. 22(7)(a) as an exception to Art. 22(4). The intercession of an advisory board in preventive detention cases for over three months being the normal rule, its dispensation could be justified only in exceptional and extraordinary cases. Therefore, the law under Art. 22(7)(a) would by its nature be a drastic law and should, therefore, apply to exceptional circumstances and exceptional activities, expressly and in precise terms prescribed by Parliament. Therefore, the word and in Art. 22(7)(a) should be interpreted to have its ordinary conjunctive sense requiring Parliament to prescribe both the 'circumstances' under which, and the 'class of cases' in which only, consideration by the Board could be dispensed with. Merely repeating verbatim the heads of legislation for preventive detention as given in entry 9 in List I and entry 3, List III40 would not satisfy Art. 22(7)(a). It would neither be prescribing 'circumstances' nor the 'classes of cases' to which only, as against the rest of the individuals, the safeguard of intercession of an independent body does not apply. Parliament must apply its mind and prescribe specific situations and types of cases which require a drastic treatment by way of dispensation of the advisory board. This pronouncement of the Court is in line with the judicial philosophy of protecting freedoms of the individuals against undue interference by the Legislature and the Executive. The result of this pronouncement is to circumscribe somewhat Parliament's scope of curtailing the safeguard of an advisory board in preventive detention cases. It may also be noted that only Parliament, and not a State Legislature, is entitled to legislate under Art. 22(7)(a) for dispensation of an advisory board in cases of preventive detention for over three months. Page 1327 Section 9 of COFEPOSA lays downs the cases in which, and the circumstances under which, persons may be detained for longer than 3 months but not exceeding 6 months without obtaining the opinion of the advisory board.41 (g) MAXIMUM PERIOD OF DETENTION Art. 22(4)(a) says that no person can be detained beyond the maximum period prescribed by any law made by Parliament. Under Art. 22(7)(b), Parliament may by law prescribe the maximum period of detention for which any person can be detained.

says that no person can be detained beyond the maximum period prescribed by any law made by Parliament. Under Art. 22(7)(b), Parliament may by law prescribe the maximum period of detention for which any person can be detained. This provision has been held to be merely permissive, and it does not oblige Parliament to prescribe any maximum period of detention. It has also been held that it is not necessary for Parliament to fix the maximum period for detention in terms of years, months or days. It is valid to fix such period in terms of a specific event, as for example, until the expiry of the emergency proclaimed under Art. 352.42 C. LAWS AUTHORISING PREVENTIVE DETENTION There exist a number of Central and State laws authorising preventive detention on various grounds. Some of these are mentioned below. (i) Central Laws The salient features of three Central Laws are discussed below. (a) NATIONAL SECURITY ACT Immediately after the inauguration of the Constitution, Parliament enacted the Preventive Detention Act, 1950. It was deemed to be a temporary measure but it remained in operation till December 31, 1969, when it was allowed to expire. It was this Act which gave rise to the famous (or, now infamous) Gopalan case.43Then was enacted the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971, (MISA). This Act lasted until 1977. Thereafter, Parliament enacted the National Security Act, 1980, (NSA). This is the prevailing law on preventive detention. The provisions of the Act of 1950 were rather severe, but, with the passage of time, the law of preventive detention has been somewhat liberalised, especially, in its procedural aspects, with a view to give better safeguards to the detenu. The salient feature of NSA is that an order of preventive detention can be made by the Central or State Government if it is satisfied with respect to any person that it is necessary to do so to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the defence of India, the relations of India with foreign powers, security of India, security of a State, maintenance of public order, or the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community [ Ss. 3(1) and 3(2)]. These are all the grounds mentioned in the two legislative entries in Lists I and III.44 A district magistrate can make such an order on the last three grounds, viz., the grounds which fall within List III, if authorised to do so by the State Government. As a safeguard against misuse of power by a district magistrate, he is required forthwith to communicate to the State Government concerned the fact of his making the order along with necessary particulars, and an order made by him cannot remain in force for more than 12 days unless approved by the State Government in the meantime [ s. 3(4)]. A State Government making or approving the order has to report the fact to the Central Government within seven days along with the necessary particulars [ s. 3(5)]. It is the Central Government's duty to consider the report. This is a statutory obligation of the Central Government.45 This is to enable the Central Government to keep some control over the State Governments in this area. Provisions have been made for communication of grounds to the detenu ordinarily not later than five days and, in exceptional circumstances, and for reasons to be recorded in writing, within 10 days of his arrest,46 Page 1328 and for giving him the earliest opportunity to make a representation against his detention to the government concerned as envisaged by Art. 22(5) [ s. 8(1)]. The authority is not required to disclose facts which it considers to be against the public interest to disclose [ s. 8(2)].47 This provision is in accordance with Art. 22(6) mentioned above. Provisions have been made in the Act for constituting advisory boards in terms of Art. 22(4). A board is to consist of three persons qualified to act as the High Court Judges, and one of the members, who is or has been a High Court Judge, is to act as its chairman [ s. 9]. The government is to place before the board within 21 days of the date of detention, the grounds of detention, detenu's representation and the report of the detaining officer [ s. 10]. The board is to submit its report within seven weeks of the date of detention [ s. 11(1)]. The board can call for such further information as it may deem necessary from the government or the detenu or any other person [ s. 11(1)]. The board can hear the detenu personally if it considers it essential, or if the detenu desires to be heard [ s. 11(1)]. The detenu cannot appear before the board through a legal practitioner [ s. 11(4)]. The board is to specify whether or not in its opinion there is sufficient cause for the detention of the person concerned [ s. 11(2)]. If the board reports in favour of detention, the government may confirm the detention order and continue his detention for such period as it thinks fit [ s. 12(1)]. In case the board reports unfavourably, the order of detention is to be revoked and the person released forthwith [ s. 12(2)]. The government concerned has power to revoke the order at any time, [ s. 14], or to release a detenu on parole conditionally or unconditionally [ s. 15]. In case of revocation, a fresh detention order can be made against the same person [ s. 14(2)]. The maximum period for which a person can be detained under the Act is twelve months [ s. 13]. The constitutional validity of NSA came to be considered by the Supreme Court in A.K. Roy v. Union of India .48 The Court rejected the contention that preventive detention was basically impermissible under the Indian Constitution. The main argument against the validity of NSA was formulated as follows: Under S.

main argument against the validity of NSA was formulated as follows: Under S. 3 of the Act, an order of preventive detention can be made if the Government is satisfied that it is necessary to do so to prevent a person from acting in any manner prejudicial to the defence of India, the relations of India with foreign powers, security of India, security of the State, maintenance of public order, or maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community. The vagueness of these expressions confers "uncontrolled discretion" on the detaining authority to expand the horizon of the power to detain, to the detriment of the liberty of the subject. The various phrases occurring in S. 3 such as 'defence of India', etc., are so vague, general and elastic that even conduct otherwise lawful can be comprehended therein depending upon the "whim and caprice" of the detaining authority. These expressions have been picked up from the relevant legislative entries in the Constitution without any attempt being made at making them precise or definite. Accepting the proposition that the vagueness and the consequent uncertainty of a preventive detention law bears upon its reasonableness, for a person "cannot be deprived of his liberty by a law which is nebulous and uncertain in its definition and application,"49 the Supreme Court, nevertheless, refused to hold the NSA invalid on this ground. According to the Court, the various expressions used in the Act relate to concepts "which are difficult to encase within the strait-jacket of a definition", "are not of any great certainty or definiteness," and are not capable of a precise definition, but they "do not elude a just application to practical situations."50S. 3 cannot, therefore, be struck down for vagueness and uncertainty. The Court explained itself thus:51 "...there are expressions which inherently comprehend such an infinite variety of situations that definitions, instead of lending to them a definite meaning, can only succeed either in robbing them to their intended amplitude or in making it necessary to frame further definitions of the terms defined." However, the Court did issue a caution: since these concepts are not defined, the Courts must strive to give them a "narrower construction than what the literal words suggest". The National Security Act must be restricted in its application to as few situations as possible and it is on this "unstated premise" that the Page 1329 constitutionality ofS. 3 may be upheld which contains clauses "which are fraught with grave consequences to personal liberty, if construed liberally". The Court did however find the expression concerning 'maintenance of supplies' to be vague. It does not make clear as to which 'supplies' or 'services' are regarded essential to the community. In the absence of a definition of 'supplies and services essential to the community', the detaining authority can extend the application of this clause to any commodities or services which it regards essential to the community. The particular clause is not only vague and uncertain but is capable of being extended cavalierly to supplies, the maintenance of which may not be essential to the community. The clause "is, therefore, capable of wanton abuse in that the detaining authority can place under detention any person for possession of any commodity on the basis that the authority is of the opinion that the maintenance of supply of that commodity is essential to the community". "To allow the personal liberty of the people to be taken away by the application of that clause would be a flagrant violation of the fairness and justness of procedure which is implicit in the provisions of Art. 21." The Court thought that the legislature could easily define which supplies and services are essential to the community. The Court however did not strike down the clause for "it is vitally necessary to ensure as steady flow of supplies and services which are essential to the community," but, instead, ruled that no person should be detained under that clause unless, "by a law, order or notification made or published fairly in advance, the supplies and services, the maintenance of which is regarded as essential to the community and in respect of which the order of detention is proposed to be passed, are made known appropriately, to the public".52 The NSA confers power to detain persons on the district magistrate, or the commissioner of police, when authorised by the State Government to do so. This was challenged as wholly unreasonable, but the Court refused the challenge in Roy arguing as follows: (i) the law contains a number of safeguards subject to which only these officers can exercise the said power; (ii) the State Government can confer such a power on these officers only if the government is satisfied that having regard to the circumstances prevailing or likely to prevail in any area, it is necessary to empower these officers to take action; (iii) the power is given for a limited period specified in the order of the State Government--authority being given for three months at a time; (iv) they can pass orders only on three grounds, viz., security of State, public order, essential supplies and services; (v) the officer has to report forthwith the fact of detention to the State Government; and (vi) no such order of detention can remain in force for more than 12 days unless approved by the government. In view of these inbuilt safeguards, according to the Court, the power conferred on the district magistrate or the commissioner of police to pass orders of preventive detention cannot be said to be excessive or unreasonable. (b) COFEPOSA ACT Besides NSA, Parliament has also enacted the Conservation of Foreign Exchange and Prevention of Smuggling Activities Act, 1974, (COFEPOSA). This Act provides for preventive detention with a view to prevent smuggling and to prevent any one from acting in a manner prejudicial to conserving and augmenting foreign exchange.

COFEPOSA ACT Besides NSA, Parliament has also enacted the Conservation of Foreign Exchange and Prevention of Smuggling Activities Act, 1974, (COFEPOSA). This Act provides for preventive detention with a view to prevent smuggling and to prevent any one from acting in a manner prejudicial to conserving and augmenting foreign exchange. The Act contemplates two situations for making orders of preventive detention (a) to prevent violation of foreign exchange regulations; and (b) to prevent smuggling activities If any of the above situations exist in the opinion of the concerned authority, he can pass an order of preventive detention. It is not necessary to detain a person that he be involved in a criminal offence. Preventive detention and prosecution for an offence are entirely different concepts.53 The Act was enacted as violations of foreign exchange regulations and smuggling activities were having an increasingly deleterious effect on the national economy and thereby a serious adverse effect on the security of state. The Act became necessary because ordinary laws did not prove effective enough to curb smuggling of goods into India. The Act derives its validity from entry 36, List I,54 read with the residuary powers of Page 1330 Parliament.55 Most of its provisions are similar to NSA. The Act fulfils all the requirements of Art. 22 as mentioned above. The power to detain is to be exercised on being satisfied with respect to any person that with a view to preventing him from including in any prejudicial activity specified in S. 3, it is necessary to make an order for his detention. Under this Act, as laid down in S. 3(1), and order of detention can be passed by--(i) Central Government; (ii) an officer of the Central Government, not below a joint secretary, especially empowered for the purpose; (iii) State Government; or (iv) an officer of the State Government not below the rank of Secretary, especially empowered for the purpose. The Supreme Court has ruled in Sushila,56 that even when an order is passed by a especially empowered officer, the order is still to be regarded as the order of the Central/State Government, as the case may be. The detenu has a right to make his representation against his detention to the appropriate government and not to the empowered officer who actually made the order of detention. COFEPOSA Act has been held to be constitutionally valid as it is relatable to Entry 3, List III, as the Act provides for preventive detention for reasons connected with the security of state as well as the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community. In Attorney General for India v. Amratlal Prajivandas, 57 the Supreme Courthas defined the term "security of state" used in Entry 3, List III, very broadly. The security of state is affected by its weak and vulnerable economy. A state with weak economy falls an easy prey to economic colonisers. "In the modern world, the security of a state" is ensured not so much by physical might but by economic strength--at any rate, by economic strength as much as by armed might". Thus, COFEPOSA Act is related to "security of state".58 Violations of foreign exchange regulations and smuggling activities have a deleterious effect on the national economy thereby casting serious adverse effect on the security of state. In any case, COFEPOSA Act can be justified under Parliament's residuary power under Art. 248 read with entry 97, List I.59As the Act does not fall under any entry in List II, it is not necessary for the court to enquire to which Entry or Entries does the Act relate. It must be held that the Parliament did have the competence to enact the Act.60 Under the COFEPOSA Act, an order of detention can be made either by the State or the Central Government. Under S. 11(b), the Central Government may, at any time, revoke or modify any order made by the State Government. When an order is made by the State Government, it is the detaining authority under Art. 22(5) and the detenu can make a representation to the State Government against his detention.61 But the detenu can also make a representation to the Central Government, although it is not the detaining authority under Art. 22(5), after his representation to the State Government, which is the detaining authority, has been rejected. The Supreme Court has ruled that though the Central Government, strictly speaking, is not the detaining authority within the meaning of Art. 22(5), the power of the Central Government to revoke the order implies that the detenu can make a representation to the Central Government to exercise its power to revoke the order. The Central Government has to consider the representation with reasonable expedition. If there is undue delay on the part of the Central Government in considering the representation and if there is no satisfactory explanation for such delay, the detention order may be quashed. This power of the Central Government is thus an additional safeguard to the detenu against the improper exercise of its power of detention by the detaining authority.62 (c) PBMSECA In addition to the above mentioned two statutes, Parliament has also enacted the Prevention of Blackmarketing and Maintenance of Supplies of Essential Commodities Act, 1980 (PBMSECA). TheAct authorises the Central or State Government to make an order detaining a person with a view to prevent him from committing black marketing and from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies of commodities essential to the community. The Act contains the usual provisions for communicating grounds of detention to the detenu, his making of a representation, reference of the case to an advisory board, etc. These provisions are mostly similar to NSA and in conformity with Art. 22, as mentioned above. Page 1331 To co-ordinate the scope of this Act with the National Security Act, the expression used in the NSA,viz., "maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community" is not to include the expression used in the Blackmarketing Act, viz.

of supplies of commodities essential to the community." Accordingly, no order of detention is to be made under the NSA on any ground on which an order of detention may be made under the PBMSECA.63The expression used in this Actmainly means committing or instigating any person to commit an offence punishable under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955, or under any other law relating to the control of the production, supply or distribution of, or trade and commerce in any commodity essential to the community, or dealing in an essential commodity with a view to making gain in a manner defeating the statutory provisions.64 (ii) State Laws Besides the Central Acts mentioned above, there are several State statutes authorising preventive detention for various purposes, e.g., The Tamil Nadu Prevention of Dangerous Activities of Bootleggers, Drug Offenders, Forest Offenders, Goondas, Immoral Traffic Offenders and Slum Grabbers Act, 1982; The Gujarat Prevention of Anti-Social Activities Act, 1985; The Bihar Control of Crimes Act, 1981; The Maharashtra Prevention of Dangerous Activities of Slumlords, Bootleggers, Drug Offenders And Dangerous Persons Act, 1981; The Andhra Pradesh Prevention of Dangerous Activities of Bootleggers, Dacoits, Drug Offenders, Goondas, Immoral Traffic Offenders and Land Grabbers Act, 1986. D. JUDICIAL REVIEW OF ORDERS OF PREVENTIVE DETENTION The area of preventive detention is very much administrative-ridden. The law of preventive detention has been so designed as to leave a very broad discretion with administrative authorities to order preventive detention of a person, and leave only a narrow margin for judicial review. However, the courts have been conscious of the fact that preventive detention affects one of the most cherished rights of a human being, namely, the freedom of his person and have, therefore, gradually evolved a few principles to control administrative discretion in the area in order to safeguard the individual's freedom from undue exercise of power. The Courts have achieved this by construing the relevant provisions of Art. 22 liberally, by insisting that the provisions of the specific law under which an order of preventive detention is made should be observed scrupulously, and by applying vigorously and creatively some of the principles of administrative law controlling administrative discretion. The Supreme Court has itself defined its role, when the liberty of a person is involved under a law of preventive detention, as follows: "It is the bounden duty of the court to satisfy itself that all the safeguards provided by the law have been scrupulously observed and that the subject is not deprived of his personal liberty otherwise than in accordance with law." The Courts have adopted not a mechanical view of their role but a purposeful approach to draw a fine balance between individual freedom and social control. The Courts have thus endeavored to soften the rigours of the law somewhat. The law of preventive detention has been a very contentious measure and has given rise to a catena of cases and it will not be an exaggeration to say that by now a distinct jurisprudence of preventive detention has been evolved in the country. The Supreme Court's interpretation of Art. 22 has already been discussed earlier in this Chapter. Some of the other judicially established propositions concerning preventive detention are noted below.65 On the whole, the Supreme Court has played a very creative role in this area as its constant endeavour has been to create by judicial interpretation of the relevant provisions as many safeguards--procedural as well as substantive--as possible, and, thus, somewhat to mitigate the harshness of the law. An order of preventive detention to be valid has to conform with the requirements laid down in Art. 22 as well as those laid down in the specific statute under which the order has been made. The Supreme Court has always placed the Page 1332 burden of showing that the detention is in accordance with the procedure established by law on the detaining authority because of Art. 21.66 On this points, the Supreme Court has observed in Icchu Devi v. Union of India :67 "This constitutional right of life and personal liberty is placed on such a high pedestal by this Court that it has always insisted that whenever there is any deprivation of life or personal liberty, the authority responsible for such deprivation must satisfy the Court that it has acted in accordance with the law. This is an area where the Court has been most strict and scrupulous in ensuring with the requirements of the law... The Court has always regarded personal liberty as the most precious possession of mankind and refused to tolerate illegal detention, regardless of the social cost involved..." The Supreme Court has emphasized from time to time that personal liberty is one of the most cherished values of mankind; without it, life will not be worth living and, it is, therefore, necessary that the courts always lean in favour of upholding personal liberty. The power of preventing detention is an extraordinary power which can be exercised strictly in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution and the law. As preventive detention encroaches upon personal liberty, it is the solemn duty of the courts to ensure that this power is exercised strictly in accordance with the requirements of the Constitution and the law. Even a slight deviation from the law may result in the order of preventive detention being quashed. If there is a breach of any legal provision, the rule of law requires that the detenu must be set at liberty, howsoever wicked or mischievous he may be. Thus, continued detention of a detenu becomes illegal because of non-compliance with statutory and constitutional requirements. The Court has emphasized from time to time that the power of preventive detention being a "draconian" power, it is tolerated in a free society, as a "necessary evil".

Supreme Court has emphasized recently in V.C. Mohan v. Union of India :68 "The accepted methodology of governmental working should always be intune with the concept of fairness and not de hors the same--a person is being placed under detention without trial and there is neither any scope for overzealous nor acting in a manner without due and proper application of mind--in either situation law courts should be able to protect the individual from the administrative ipse dixit." The Supreme Court has ruled in Sunil Fulchand Shah v. Union of India, 69 that when the High Court quashes an order of detention resulting in the release of the detenu, but, on appeal, the High Court decision is reversed, the question whether or not the detenu ought to be made to surrender to undergo the remaining period of detention depends upon many factors and, in particular, on the question of lapse of time between the date of detention, the order of the High Court setting aside the order of detention, and the order of the Supreme Court setting aside the High Court order. (a) NO OBJECTIVE STANDARD NECESSARY A law of preventive detention is not invalid because it prescribes no objective standard for ordering preventive detention, and leaves the matter to the subjective satisfaction of the executive. The reason for this view is that preventive detention is not punitive but preventive and is resorted to with a view to prevent a person from committing activities regarded as prejudicial to certain objects which the law of preventive detention seeks to prescribe. Preventive detention is thus based on suspicion or anticipation and not on proof. It is, therefore, not possible to lay down objective rules of conduct non-observance of which should lead to preventive detention. The responsibility for security of state, or maintenance of public order, or essential services and supplies rests on the executive and it must, therefore, have the necessary power to order preventive detention. The subjective satisfaction of a detaining authority to detain a person or not is not open to objective assessment by a Court. A Court is not a proper forum to scrutinise the merits of the administrative decision to detain a person. The Court cannot substitute its own satisfaction for that of the authority concerned and decide whether its satisfaction was reasonable or proper, or whether in the circumstances of the matter, the person concerned should have been detained or not.70 The Supreme Court has stated the position as Page 1333 follows: "When power is given to an authority to act on certain facts and if that authority acts on relevant facts and arrives at a decision which cannot be described as either irrational or unreasonable; in the sense that no person instructed in law could have reasonably taken that view, then the order is not bad and the court cannot substitute its decision or opinion, in place of the decision of the authority concerned on the necessity of passing the order".71 The Courts do not even go into the question whether the facts mentioned in the grounds of detention are correct or false. The reason for the rule is that to decide this, evidence may have to be taken by the Courts and that is not the policy of the law of preventive detention. This matter lies within the competence of the advisory board.72 The Court has pointed out that as far as the factor of releasing on bail is concerned, the only requirement is that the Detaining Authority should be aware that the detenu is already in custody and is likely to be released to bail and if there were materials before the authority to come to the conclusion that there was likelihood of the detenu being released on bail the court will not interfere with such subjective satisfaction of the authority.73 Although even a solitary instance may be the basis of a subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority, its precedence and nature of activities carried out are required to be taken into consideration for reaching a justifiable satisfaction that the person was engaged in smuggling and that with a view to prevent it, it was necessary to detain him.74 (b) CIRCUMSTANCES VITIATING SUBJECTIVE SATISFACTION Whatever has been said above, however, does not mean that the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority is completely unreviewable. There are a number of principles of Administrative Law which the courts frequently invoke to control the discretion of the detaining authority to some extent. Thus, satisfaction of the detaining authority can be called in question inter alia on such grounds as mala fides, non-application of the authority's mind to the case of the detenu,75 subjective satisfaction being based on irrelevant grounds, etc. The satisfaction of the detaining authority must be grounded on materials of rationally probative value and it should not be arrived at without taking into account relevant factors. Discretion should not be arbitrary, vague, fanciful but should be legal and regular. If the detaining authority comes to a conclusion so unreasonably that no reasonable person could have ever come to it, the court can interfere.76 A detention order can be quashed if any relevant material is not placed before the detaining authority.77 As the Supreme Court has observed in this connection : "The satisfaction of the detaining authority is not a subjective one based on the detaining authority's emotions, beliefs or prejudices. There must be a real likelihood of the person being able to indulge in such activities, the inference of such likelihood being drawn from objective data."78 The Court does not, of course, go into the 'adequacy or sufficiency' of the grounds on which the order of detention is based but merely examines whether, on the grounds given to the detenu, a reasonable person could possibly have come to the conclusion to which the detaining authority did.

the dividing line between subjective satisfaction and objective determination becomes rather blurred, but the line is still there howsoever faint it may be.79 (c) NON-CONSIDERATION OF A MATERIAL FACT Formation of subjective satisfaction on the part of the detaining authority may be vitiated if a material or vital fact which may have a bearing on the issue and may influence the mind of the detaining authority one way or other is not considered by the detaining authority before issuing the detention order.80 The Supreme Court has laid down the following proposition in Asha Devi:81 "... If material or vital facts which would influence the minds of the detaining authority one way or the other on the question whether or not to make the detention order, are not placed before or are not considered by the detaining authority it would vitiate its subjective satisfaction rendering the detention order illegal". Page 1334 In the instant case, one such fact may be that the person against whom a detention order is proposed to be issued is being prosecuted for an offence. The fact that a criminal case is pending against the person against whom an order of preventive detention is going to be issued is a very material circumstance which ought to be placed before the detaining authority. This circumstance might quite possibly have an impact on his decision whether or not to make an order of detention. It is not altogether unlikely that the authority may take the view that since a criminal case is pending against the person sought to be detained, no detention order need be made for the present, but the criminal case should be allowed to run its full course, and only if it fails to end in conviction, then preventive detention should be resorted to.82 Similarly, if any enquiry into allegations of criminal activity is inconclusive and pending consideration, the same cannot be the basis for passing an order against the person concerned.83 (d) NON-APPLICATION OF MIND An order of preventive detention can be quashed if the authority passes it mechanically and without applying its mind.84 The liberty of a person is a serious matter and it cannot be trifled with in a casual, indifferent and routine manner. At times, some formal defect in the order of the preventive detention may be regarded by the Court as indicating non-application of mind by the authority making the order. NSA authorises preventive detention on several grounds. The order of detention, should, therefore, specify the ground or grounds on which detention has been ordered. An order will be bad if it says that the detention has been ordered on ground (a) or ground (b). Thus, an order saying that the petitioner was being detained with a view to preventing him from acting in a manner 'prejudicial to the maintenance of the public order' or 'security of state', was bad. 'Public order' and 'security of state' are two separate grounds of detention under NSA. If the prejudicial activities of the petitioner affected both these grounds, then the order should have used the conjunctive 'and' instead of the disjunctive 'or'. The use of the word 'or' indicates that the detaining authority was either not certain of, or did not apply its mind to, whether the petitioner's activities fell under one head or the other and merely reproduced mechanically the statutory formula.85 The Home Department of Bengal Government followed the practice of issuing a detention order automatically whenever the police recommended it, and the Home Secretary did not personally satisfy himself on the materials placed before him whether it was necessary to issue such an order in a particular case or not. A detention order issued in such a routine manner was quashed by the Privy Council in Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji86 on the ground that the Home Secretary had not applied his mind to the question of issuing the order and that his personal satisfaction in each case of detention was a condition precedent to the issue of such an order. In a detention order, the grounds of detention were a verbatim reproduction of the allegation made against the detenu in a police dossier submitted to the detaining authority who was not even aware that the detenu was in custody at the time the order was issued. Quashing the order, the Supreme Court observed: "We are afraid it is difficult to find greater proof of non-application of mind."87 Glaring factual errors in the grounds served on a detenu may lead to the inference that the order was issued without proper application of mind by the detaining authority.88 An order passed by a district magistrate on the direction of a senior officer, but without having any grounds on record against the concerned person is void. The magistrate can pass an order when he is himself personally satisfied on the materials before him. He ought not to pass an order mechanically or under any body else's dictates.89 (e) MALA FIDES The Courts quash an order of detention if mala fides of the detaining authority are established. A kerosene dealer was detained. He alleged in the Court that the Deputy Superintendent of Police, at whose Page 1335 instance the order was issued, had made false reports against him so that he could be eliminated as a wholesale kerosene dealer and D.S.P.'s relatives might be benefited by obtaining the distributorship for kerosene. On the basis of the affidavits filed, the Supreme Court found some substance in these allegations and ruled that the detention order was 'clearly and plainly mala fide'.90 Will a detention order be regarded as mala fide and hence invalid because it is made against a person on the very same grounds on which he had been earlier prosecuted in a Court but dischargd?

can plausibly be argued that preventive detention in such a situation circumvents the ordinary law of the land and defeats the Court's order and what better proof of the detaining authority's mala fides could there be than its use of its extrarodinary powers of preventive detention when a person had been acquitted or discharged by a court. However, generally speaking, the mere fact that criminal proceedings had been initiated against a person for certain incidents and that he was discharged by the Court would neitherbar a valid detention order being passed against him on the basis of these very incidents nor can such an order for that reason be characterised as mala fide. The rationale of this judicial view is that while the purpose of trial and punishment is punitive and it seeks to punish for past offences and, therefore, needs proof beyond reasonable doubt, the purpose of preventive detention is 'preventive'. It is a precautionary measure and is based on a reasonable prognosis of the future behaviour of a person based on his past conduct in the light of surrounding circumstances. Therefore, while there may not be evidence sufficient to prove him guilty in a court, it may be sufficient to sustain the subjective satisfaction to order detention.91 Many a time, the prosecution fails because witnesses are afraid to depose against desperate characters, but detaining authorities may be satisfied on the basis of the past activities of the person concerned that it was necessary to detain him to prevent him from committing prejudicial activities.92 Nor can a detention order be held bad on the ground that it is based on such grounds as could be tried under the criminal law, and that the accused should have been so tried instead of being detained.93 What, however, has been said above is not a universal rule, and there may be extreme cases and exceptional circumstances when a prior court case, or lack of it, may be a factor in invalidating detention. The Courts have been conscious of the danger that the executive may tend to shy away from Court proceedings for bringing home to the person concerned his guilt in the normal manner, and, instead, adopt the easier strategy of issuing preventive detention orders based on their subjective satisfaction. Such a tendency, if allowed unchecked, may pose a danger to the democratic way of life. Referring to this aspect of the matter, the Supreme Court observed in Bhut Nath v. State of West Bengal .1"...detention power cannot be quietly used to subvert, supplant or to substitute the punitive law of the Penal Code. The immune expedient of throwing into a prison cell one whom ordinary law would take care of, merely because it is irksome to undertake the inconvenience of proving guilt in Court is unfair abuse." In a case, the facts may so clearly indicate that an ordinary criminal prosecution would suffice and the need to make preventive detention order might not be reasonably made out.2 The Supreme Court has thus been cautious in this area, and has read some qualifications in the rules abovementioned. In Vijay Narain Singh,3 the Supreme Court has stated that the law of preventive detention being a drastic law it must be strictly construed and should not ordinarily be used for clipping the wings of an accused if criminal prosecution would suffice. Again, in Ramesh Yadav,4 the Supreme Court has stated that ordinarily a detention order should not be passed merely on the ground that the detenu who was carrying on smuggling activities was likely to be enlarged on bail. In such a case, the proper course would be to oppose the bail application. If it is granted then the decision ought to be challenged in the higher forum but it should not be circumvented by passing an order of detention merely to supersede the bail order. The same principle has been reiterated by the Supreme Court in Suraj Pal Sahu.5 A preventive detention order served on a person on the self-same grounds on which he was being prosecuted was declared invalid in Biram Chand v. Uttar Pradesh6 on the ground that--(i) two parallel proceedings--prosecution as well as detention--should not be takensimultaneously against a person; (ii) a Page 1336 person faced with a criminal charge and prosecution, has no proper and reasonable opportunity to make an effective representation against his detention; (iii) the fact that a criminal prosecution is pending against a person is not a relevant ground for making a detention order. This was impeccable logic, but in Haradhan Saha v. State of West Bengal, 7 the Supreme Court dissented with this view and held that a detention order passed during the pendency of the prosecution would not be invalid. In Srilal Shaw v. State of West Bengal, 8 a preventive order was issued against a person mainly on the ground that he had stolen railway property. He had documents to show that he had purchased the goods in question in the open market. A criminal case filed against him was dropped and detention order passed instead. A three Judge Bench of the Supreme Court declared the order bad. The Court thought that it was a typical case where for no apparent reason a person who could easily be prosecuted under the punitive law was being preventively detained. The Court noted that Parliament had enacted a special law which conferred extensive powers on the executive to bring to book persons found in unlawful possession of railway property. If the facts stated were true then it was an easy case to take to the successful conclusion. The Court felt that the criminal case against the detenu was probably dropped because he might have been able to prove his innocence.

Court felt that the criminal case against the detenu was probably dropped because he might have been able to prove his innocence. The Court, therefore, held that, on the basis of the material available to the detaining authority, 'it was impossible to arrive at the conclusion that the possession of the petitioner was unlawful'.9 The Court adopted the Shaw ruling instead of the Saha ruling in L.K. Das v. State of West Bengal10 and held a detention order bad as being based on a 'simple, solitary incident of theft' without anything more. The government's contention that the prosecution could not be pursued in the case as the witnesses were afraid to give evidence against the person concerned was rejected by the Court as being 'fanciful', repugnant to reason and reality and one, which could not be swallowed even by an ultra-credulous man, because all the witnesses were members of the railway force. In Noor Chand v. State of West Bengal, 11 the Supreme Court emphasized that the fact that the petitioner was discharged from the criminal cases was not entirely irrelevant and it was a circumstance which the detaining authority could not altogether disregard. In this case, the petitioner had been discharged in a criminal trial but then detained. He claimed that he had been discharged because there was no material against him and not because witnesses were afraid to give evidence. The witnesses in the case were members of the railway protection force and there was no question of these people being afraid to give evidence. The magistrate detaining the person did not file an affidavit controverting the suggestion made by the detenu. The Court found it an infirmity that the detaining authority did not assert that in spite of the discharge he was satisfied, on some valid material, about the petitioner's complicity in the criminal acts which constitute the basis of the 'detention order'. The Court declared that the order was a 'colourable exercise of power'. The Court felt convinced that there was no material on the basis of which the detaining authority could have been satisfied to detain the person concerned.12 The Court has thus adopted the attitude that although the subjective satisfaction of the authority is not to be tested by 'objective' standards, nevertheless, a 'sham satisfaction is no satisfaction.' The upshot of all this is that, while discharge in a criminal case by itself is not sufficient to vitiate detention later, there may be circumstances which coupled with non-prosecution in a court, or failure of prosecution, may make detention bad. The Courts do not take at its face value the assertion by the government that witnesses were afraid to testify against the detenu and hence the prosecution could not be undertaken or that it failed. Similarly, detention will be vitiated if the court had earlier declared the case to be false or baseless and the detenu was detained on the same grounds as had formed the subject-matter of the unsuccessful prosecution.13 This cautious approach of the Courts reflects its anxiety that preventive detention should not be used to supplant the ordinary judicial machinery which may become a threat to democratic values. If the Court feels satisfied that the prosecution was not undertaken, or that it failed not because the witnesses were afraid to testify but because there was no material against the detenu, then it can hold that the satisfaction of the detaining authority was 'colourable' as there was no rational basis for its satisfaction.14 Another problem which has arisen is : can an order of preventive detention be served on a person who is already in custody for some criminal charges.? As an abstract proposition of law, it can be said that the Page 1337 authority is not precluded to pass such an order, but the question may arise in a specific fact situation whether such an order was justified. For example, if a person is already sentenced to ten years' rigorous imprisonment, it is not possible to argue that an order of preventive detention may be served on him, soon after the sentence is pronounced, directing his detention after his release from the prison after the period of sentence is over. On the other hand, if a person is undergoing imprisonment for a month or so, the authority may serve a detention order to be effective after his release. If the authority is bona fide satisfied that his detention is necessary, he can make a valid detention order a few days before his release from prison. The antecedent history and the past conduct on which the order of detention would be based would, in such a case, be proximate in point of time and would have a rational connection with the conclusion drawn by the authority that the detention of the person after his release is necessary. Therefore, the question whether an order of detention can be passed against a person who is in jail, has to be determined in the circumstances of each case.15 (a) In the following cases, preventive detention orders served on persons in jail have been held valid. In Kartic Chandra Guha v. State of West Bengal, 16 [e4] the order was held valid as there was a likelihood of the detenu being released on bail and resuming his prejudicial activities. In Dr. Ramakrishna Rawat v. District Magistrate, Jabalpur, 17 the order of detention was passed as the detenu was in jail custody for a short duration. On the basis of his antecedent activities, the detaining authority could reasonably reach his subjective satisfaction that the detenu would act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.18 (b) In the following cases, the orders of preventive detention served on persons in jail have been quashed. In Shashi19, the order was quashed as there was no material or record that the detenu, if released on bail, was likely to commit activities prejudicial to maintenance of public order. In Meera Rani,20 the order of preventive detention was quashed.

Shashi19, the order was quashed as there was no material or record that the detenu, if released on bail, was likely to commit activities prejudicial to maintenance of public order. In Meera Rani,20 the order of preventive detention was quashed. Although the detaining authority was aware that the detenu was in jail at the time, there was nothing to show that the detaining authority considered it likely that the detenu could be released on bail. The Court laid down the applicable principle in these cases in the following words: "Subsisting custody of the detenu by itself does not invalidate an order of his preventive detention and the decision must depend on the facts of the particular case; preventive detention being necessary to prevent the detenu from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the state or to the maintenance of public order etc., ordinarily it is not needed when the detenu is already in custody; the detaining authority must show its awareness to the fact of subsisting custody of the detenu and take that factor into account while making the order; but, even so, if the detaining authority is reasonably satisfied on cogent material that there is likelihood of his release and in view of his antecedent activities which are proximate in point of time he must be detained in order to prevent him from indulging in such prejudicial activities, the detention order can be validly made even in anticipation to operate on his release". The Supreme Court has held in Binod Singh21 that if a person is in custody and there is no imminent possibility of his being released therefrom, the power of the detention should not ordinarily be exercised. Before passing a detention order in respect of a person who is already in jail, the concerned authority must satisfy itself, and that satisfaction must be reached on the basis of cogent material, that there is a real possibility of the detenu being released on bail, and that if released on bail, the material on record reveals that he will indulge in prejudicial activity if not detained. In Poonam Lata v. M.L. Wadhwan, 22 the Supreme Court has explained the position thus: the fact that the detenu is already in detention does not take away the jurisdiction of the detaining authority in making an order of preventive detention. What is necessary in such a case is to satisfy the court when detention is challenged on that ground that the detaining authority was aware of the fact that the detenu was already in custody and yet he was subjectively satisfied that the order of detention was necessary. In the instant case, there was sufficient material to show that the detaining authority was aware that the petitioner was in custody when the order was made, yet he was satisfied that his preventive detention was necessary. Page 1338 In Abdul Razak Sheikh,23 the detention order was quashed on the ground of non-application of mind as it was found that the detaining authority was unaware that the detenu's application for bail was rejected by the concerned Court.24 In Sanjeev Kumar Aggarwal v. Union of India, 25 a detention order was served on the detenu who was already in jail as it was apprehended that he would indulge in prejudicial activities on being released on bail. Upholding the order, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no law to say that no detention order could validly be passed against a person in custody under any circumstances. The facts and circumstances of each case have to be taken into consideration to consider the validity of a detention order passed when the detenu is in jail. In the instant case, the Court felt satisfied that the order could not be quashed because of the following circumstances: the order was passed under COFEPOSA; the detaining authority was aware that the detenu was in jail; the detaining authority felt satisfied that the detenu was likely to come out on bail and, thereafter, would again indulge in smuggling. In Kamarunissa v. Union of India, 26 the Supreme Court has recently derived the following propositions from the catena of decisions on preventive detention: even in case of a person in custody a detention order can validly be passed-- (1) if the authority passing the order is aware of the fact that he is actually in custody; (2) if he has reason to believe on the basis of reliable material placed before him (a) that there is a real possibility of his being released on bail, and (b) that on being so released he would in all probability indulge in prejudicial activity; and (3) if it is felt essential to detain him to prevent him from doing so. If the authority passes an order after recording his satisfaction in this behalf, such an order cannot be struck down on the ground that the proper course for the authority would be to oppose the bail and if bail was granted notwithstanding such opposition to question it before a higher court. The Supreme Court has observed in this connection: "It seems to us well-settled that even in a case where a person is in custody, if the facts and circumstances of the case so demand, resort can be had to the law of preventive detention." (f) COLOURABLE EXERCISE OF POWER A detention order may be quashed on the ground of colourable exercise of power if there is no rational material for the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority, or that the material is such that no reasonable person could possibly arrive at such satisfaction on its basis.27 A considerable delay, say of two or three months, between the date of making the detention order and the arrest of the person concerned thereunder has been held to throw doubt on the genuineness of the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority.

if the authority was genuinely satisfied that it was necessary to detain the person concerned so as to prevent him from committing prejudicial activities, then the authority should act promptly to arrest him after making the order and not let him remain at large to carry on his objectionable activities. Therefore, if the authority fails to furnish a reasonable explanation for the delay, the subjective satisfaction may be inferred to be 'colourable' and not genuine.28 It is, however, not the law that whenever there is some delay in arresting, the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority must be held to be not genuine or colourable. Each case must depend on its own peculiar facts and circumstances. There must be "live and proximate link" between the grounds of detention and the avowed purpose of detention, and in some cases it is possible to assume that this link is snapped if there is a long and unexplained delay between the date of the order of detention and the arrest of the detenu.29 In Abdul Rahman,30 the detention order was passed on 7-10-87 under COFEPOSA but the detenu was arrested on 18-1-88. The detention was quashed as there was no satisfactory explanation for the delay in arresting the detenu in pursuance of the detention order. The Court observed:31 Page 1339 "...When there is unsatisfactory and unexplained delay between the date of order of detention and the date of securing the arrest of detenu, such a delay would throw considerable doubt on the genuineness of the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority leading to a legitimate inference that the detaining authority was not really and genuinely satisfied as regards the necessity for detaining the detenu with a view to preventing him from acting in a prejudicial manner". The Supreme Court has been vigilant to ensure that isolated offences are not made grounds for preventive detention because the executive may use this strategy to by-pass normal criminal judicial process. Thus, the Court has held that a solitary act of wagon breaking,32 or a simple solitary incident of theft without any thing more,33 can hardly persuade a reasonable man to reach the satisfaction that unless the person concerned was detained he would in all probability indulge in similar activities. But it may be otherwise in cases of crimes involving sophisticated technique and expertise, e.g., theft of railway signal material.34 There may be cases, like an organised and armed robbery where a single deviance may demonstrate potentiality for continuing criminality and thus sustain a detention order.35 The question in such cases is: Is the incident too flimsy or trivial to support the subjective satisfaction to detain the person concerned? Is the past activity of the detenu reasonably suggestive of a repetitive tendency on his part to likewise act in future? The Supreme Court has emphasized that the power of preventive detention is to be exercised only if the detaining authority, on the basis of the past prejudicial conduct of the detenu, is satisfied about the probability of his acting similarly in future.36 The Supreme Court has observed in Amratlal37: "Though ordinarily one act may not be held sufficient to sustain an order of detention, one act may sustain an order of detention if the act is of such a nature as to indicate that it is an organised act or a manifestation of organized activity. The gravity and nature of the act is also relevant. The test is whether the act is such that it gives rise to an inference that the person would continue to indulge in similar prejudicial activity." A detention order on the basis of a single solitary instance of exporting Indian currency was held good under COFEPOSA.38 On the other hand, a detention order under the same Act based on a single incident was quashed by the Supreme Court in the case noted below.39From the facts "it is totally unreasonable to arrive at a prognosis that the petitioner is likely to indulge in any such prejudicial activities." Similarly, in a recent case the court said that the mere fact that on one occasion a person smuggled goods into the country would not constitute a legitimate basis for detaining under the COFEPOSA Act.40 (g) NON-EXISTENT OR IRRELEVANT GROUND A detention order is bad if it is based on a non-existent ground.41 In the grounds served on a detenu, certain prejudicial activities were attributed to him on a day when he was in police custody. The order was quashed as having been based on a non-existent ground.42 A detention order should not be based on a ground which is irrelevant, or extraneous to, or falls outside, the scope and object of the law of preventive detention. The grounds on which a detention order has been made must have some rational connection with, and be relevant and germane to, the objects to prevent which the order in question has been made. A detention order based on no material but on pure speculation is not valid.43 Although the subjective satisfaction of the detaining officer is not open to objective assessment,44 nevertheless, satisfaction based on irrelevant ground is vitiated.45 The court may examine the 'grounds' specified in the order of detention to see whether they are relevant to the circumstances under which preventive detention can be supported. The test to determine the relevancy is this: are the grounds such as a rational human being can consider to be connected in some manner with the objects which are sought to be prevented?46 If the grounds relied on have nothing to do with the prejudicial purposes stipulated in the statute and the detention order, no nexus exists and the order is invalid. Even if the activities attributed to the detenu have some connection with the prohibited objectives, it should not be too trivial in substance. For instance, NSA authorises preventive detention for 'maintenance of public Page 1340 order'. 'Public order' has been judicially distinguished from 'law and order'. 'Public order" and 'law and order' are two distinct concepts.

if the activities attributed to the detenu have some connection with the prohibited objectives, it should not be too trivial in substance. For instance, NSA authorises preventive detention for 'maintenance of public Page 1340 order'. 'Public order' has been judicially distinguished from 'law and order'. 'Public order" and 'law and order' are two distinct concepts. Maintenance of 'public order' means prevention of disorder of a grave nature. An activity can be said to affect public order only if it affects the public at large.47 On the other hand, maintenance of 'law and order' means prevention of minor disorders or breaches of peace of a local nature which primarily injure specific individuals. An act affecting the current of community life is germane to 'public order'; an act affecting merely an individual leaving public tranquillity undisturbed is relevant to 'law and order' and not to 'public order'. One has to imagine three concentric circles, the largest representing "law and order", the next representing 'public order', and the smallest circle representing "security of state'. An act may affect "law and order", but not 'public order'; an act may affect "public order" but not "security of state".48 As the Supreme Court has observed in Sushanta:49 "The contravention of any law always affects order but before it can be said to affect public order it must affect the community or the public at large. A mere disturbance of law and order leading to disorder is not necessarily sufficient for action under the Act but a disturbance which will affect public order can alone justify the detention under that head." Again, the Supreme Court has observed in Gulab Mehra v. State of Uttar Pradesh :50 "...whether an act relates to law and order or to public order depends upon the effect of the act on the life of the community or in other words the reach and effect and potentiality of the act if so put as to disturb or dislocate the even tempo of the life of the community, it will be an act which will affect public order." Sometimes, a simple 'law and order' situation may assume the gravity and mischief of a 'public order' problem by reason alone of the manner or circumstances in which, or the place at which, it is carried out. Necessarily, much depends upon the nature of the act, the place where it is committed and the sinister significance attached to it.51 In the final analysis, one has to turn to the facts of each case to ascertain whether the matter relates to the larger circle or the smaller circle. When an order of detention is questioned, it is for the court to decide whether the activities in question upon which the detention order is based go under the classification of public order or belong to the category of law and order. Thus, acts of theft or robbery,52 solitary cases of assault,53 or assault on a public servant,54 a murderous assault on a person causing him grievous injuries resulting in his death55 affect only 'law and order' and are not relevant to the concept of 'public order' and a preventive detention order based on any such ground cannot be sustained. Such acts do not in any way affect the even tempo of the community life nor do they affect the peace and tranquillity of the people in the particular locality where the crime is committed. The Supreme Court has ruled in Devaki56 that a single incident of murderous assault on a minister in a public place may give rise to a 'law and order' problem but certainly not to a 'public order' problem. "This incident did not and could not affect public peace and tranquillity nor it had the potential to create a sense of alarm and insecurity in the locality". The solitary incident as alleged in the ground of detention was held by the Court as "not relevant' for sustaining the order of detention for the purpose of preventing the petitioner from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order. But highway robbery using daggers,57 murder by members of an extremist party with the object of promoting the party cause,58 possession of high explosive bombs,59 firing in public and killing people, affect public order. There may, however, be circumstances in which a criminal act against one person may amount to a problem of public order.60 A mere peaceful protest does not disturb public peace and, thus, has no nexus with 'public order'.61 In this area, Magan Gope62 is very instructive. Magan was detained on the ground inter aliathat, while engaged in the act of smuggling on a particular day, he along with his associates attacked a party of Home Guards at about 7 p.m. The Court quashed the order holding the matter to be relevant to 'law and order' and not to 'public order' because of the following reasons: there was absolutely no mention that any scare was caused within the locality as a result of the incident; it was not mentioned that the detenu and his associates were armed with any deadly weapons; the incident was confined to the detenu and his associates on the one Page 1341 hand and the Home Guards on the other. As a general proposition, the Court stated that prima facie there was no relation between smuggling from one State to another in the country which was essentially a secret operation and maintenance of public order in which the operative word is 'public'. There may, however, be cases of smuggling with violence affecting public tranquillity which may be related to 'public order'. The Supreme Court has now explained the concept of 'public order' in Amanulla Khan Pathan v. State of Gujarat .63 An activity violating an ordinary legal provision may in a given case amount to a matter of "public order".

is the magnitude of the activities and its effect on the even tempo of life of the society at large or with a section of the society that determines whether the activities can be said to be prejudicial to the maintenance of public order or not." In Mustakmiyan Jabbarmiya Shaikh v. M.M. Mehta, Commissioner of Police, 64 the Supreme Court has held that in order to bring the activities of a person within the expression "acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order", the fall out and the extent and reach of the alleged activities must be of such a nature that they travel beyond the capacity of the ordinary law to deal with him or to prevent his subversive activities affecting the community at large or a large section of the society. "It is the degree of disturbance and its impact upon the even tempo of life of the society or the people of a locality which determines whether the disturbance caused by such activity amounts only to a breach of "law and order", or it amounts to breach of "public order".65 In Amanulla Khan, the activities of the detenu by way of trying to extract money from ordinary citizens by putting them to fear of death and on their refusal to part with the money to drag them and torture them on public road undoubtedly affected the even tempo of life of the society and, therefore, such activities cannot be said to be a mere disturbance of law and order. In the view of the Supreme Court, these activities were such that "the detaining authority was satisfied that such activities amount to disturbance of public order and to prevent such disturbance the order of detention was passed". Some of the activities held relevant to the 'maintenance of supplies and services' are: stealing of batteries from railway coaches;66 hoarding of stock of goods to sell in the black market;67 theft of telephone cable;68 smuggling of rice;69 black marketing;70 theft of electric copper wire disrupting electric supply.71 An undue time-lag between the offending activity and the order of detention based on it may vitiate the order on the basis that no authority, acting rationally, can be subjectively satisfied of future mischief merely because long ago the detenu had done something evil. The past conduct of a person can appropriately be taken into account in making a detention order, for it is largely from past tendencies of a person that an inference can be drawn whether he is likely to act in future in a prejudicial manner. But such an inference is justifiable only if the past conduct is proximate in point of time and has a rational connection with the conclusion that the detention of the person is necessary. If the time-lag between the prejudicial activity by a person and the detention order made because of that activity is ex facie long, the order would be invalid unless the detaining authority should explain to the court the delay in making the order to show that there was proximity between the prejudicial activity and the detention order.72 The credible chain between the grounds of criminal activity alleged by the detaining authority and the purpose of detention, is snapped if there is too long and unexplained an interval between the offending acts and the order of detention. But no mechanical test "by counting the months of the interval" could be laid down. It all depends on the facts of the case.73 As the Supreme Court has explained.74 "Delay ipso facto in passing an order of detention is not fatal to the detention of a person, for in certain cases delay may be unavoidable and reasonable. What is required by law is that the delay must be satisfactorily examined by the detaining authority". The position has been lucidly explained by the Supreme Court in Abdul Rahman:75 "The question whether the prejudicial activities of a person necessitating to pass an order of extention is proximate to the time when the order is made or the live-link between the prejudicial activities and the purpose of detention is Page 1342 snapped depends on the facts and circumstances of each case. No hard and fast rule can be precisely formulated that would be applicable under all circumstances and no exhaustive guidelines can be laid down in that behalf. It follows that the test of proximity is not a rigid or mechanical test by merely counting number of months between the offending acts and the order of detention. However, when there is undue and long delay between the prejudicial activities and the passing of detention order, the court has to scrutinize whether the detaining authority has satisfactorily examined such a delay and afforded a tenable and reasonable explanation as to why such a delay has occasioned, when called upon to answer and further the Court has to investigate whether the causal connection has been broken in the circumstances of each case." If detention order is based on 'stale' or 'illusory' grounds, or if there is no real nexus between the grounds and the impugned order, then the order of preventive detention is invalid.76 It is now a very well-settled rule that if any one of the several grounds on which a detention order is based is either non-existent or irrelevant, then the detention order will be held to be invalid even though the other grounds may be good. The reason is that, in such a case, it can never be predicted as to what extent the bad ground operated on the mind of the detaining authority; whether relevant and admissible or irrelevant or non-existent ground gave the requisite satisfaction to the concerned authority, or whether the detention order would have been made at all if the bad ground was excluded and only the good grounds were placed before the authority making the order.77 This judicially-developed rule is sought to be diluted by statutory provisions.
