While any section of the Indian citizens including the majority can invoke Art. 29(1), Art. 30 is available only to the religious or linguistic minorities. There is a close affinity between Arts. 29(1) and 30. A minority community can best conserve its language, script or culture through educational institutions, for it is through education that the language and culture of a minority can be inculcated into the impressionable minds of the children of the community. The right to establish and maintain educational institutions of its choice by a minority is, therefore, concomitant to its right to conserve its distinctive language, script or culture, and that is what is envisaged by Art. 30(1). But it does not mean that only such minority institution is entitled to the protection of Art. 30 as is exclusively engaged in the conservation of minority language, script or culture, and that an institution of general education established by a minority cannot claim such protection. The Supreme Court ruled that Arts. 29 and 30 create two separate rights and that "the width of Art. 30(1) cannot be cut down by introducing in it considerations on which Art. 29(1) is based."81 The advantage of Art. 30 is available to all minority educational institutions and not only to those whose object is to conserve or promote the language of the minority.82 In this connection, the Supreme Court has observed in In re Kerala Education Bill :83 " Article 30(1) gives certain rights not only to religious minorities but also to linguistic minorities....the right conferred on such minorities is to establish educational institutions of their choice. It does not say that minorities based on religion should establish educational institutions for teaching religion only, or that linguistic minorities should have the right to establish educational institutions for teaching their language only. What the Art. says and means is that the religious and linguistic minorities should have the right to establish educational institutions of their choice. There is no limitation placed on the subjects to be taught in such educational institutions. As such minorities ordinarily desire that their children should be brought up properly and be eligible for higher university education and go out in the world fully equipped with such intellectual attainments as will make them fit for entering the public services, educational institutions of their choice will necessarily include institutions imparting general secular education also. In other words, the Art. leaves it to their choice to establish such educational institutions as will serve their religion, language or culture and also the purpose of giving a thorough good general education to their children."84 Article 29(1) gives general protection to minorities to conserve their language etc., while Art. 30(1) gives to them a special right to establish institutions of their 'choice'. The crucial phrase in Art. 30(1) is 'of their choice', and their 'choice' cannot be limited merely to institutions seeking to conserve language, script or culture of the minorities. Thus, a minority whether based on religion or language has a right to establish institutions of a general secular character not designed to conserve their language, etc., such as a college of general education, or a teachers' training college, etc.85 Nor is the choice of the minority taken away if in an educational institution established by it, students of other communities are also admitted. In reality, under Art. 29(2), a State-aided educational institution, even though established and run by a minority, is obligated not to deny admission to members of other communities on grounds only of religion, race, caste and language.86 A provision in the Gujarat University Act authorising the University to undertake teaching in undergraduate classes, and deprive the minority colleges from such teaching was held to infringe Art. 30(1). Similarly, a power in the University to make affiliated colleges as constituent colleges and integrate them with the University was held not applicable to minority colleges for they would thereby lose their individual and minority character.87 C. REGULATION OF MINORITY EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS (a) INTRODUCTORY The fundamental freedom under Art. 30(1) is prima facie absolute in nature as it is not made subject to any reasonable restrictions. This means that all minorities, linguistic or religious, have by Art. 30(1) right to Page 47 establish and administer educational institutions of their choice and "any law or executive direction which seeks to infringe the substance of that right under Art. 30(1) would to that extent be void." The above provision does not however mean that the state can impose no regulations on the minority institutions. As early as 1958, in the famous Kerala Education Bill, the Supreme Court has observed: "The right conferred on the religious and linguistic minorities to administer educational institutions of their choice is not an absolute right".

The above provision does not however mean that the state can impose no regulations on the minority institutions. As early as 1958, in the famous Kerala Education Bill, the Supreme Court has observed: "The right conferred on the religious and linguistic minorities to administer educational institutions of their choice is not an absolute right". Although Art. 30(1) is couched in absolute terms in marked contrast with such Fundamental Rights as are contained in Art. 19(1), it has to be read subject to the regulatory power of the state. Regulations which do not affect the substance of the guaranteed rights, but ensure the excellence of the institution and its proper functioning in matters educational, are permissible.88 Regulations could be made to maintain educational character and standard of institution. "When any regulatory measure is assailed, it would be obligatory for the court to find out as to whether the provisions in fact secures a reasonable balance between ensuring a standard of excellence of the institution and of preserving the right of the minority to administer the institution as a minority institution."89 The right to administer cannot encompass the right to maladminister. By its interpretative process over the years, the Supreme Court has given a wide sweep to the protection conferred on the minority educational institutions under Art. 30(1) as well as permitted some regulation thereof by the concerned government in the interest of the well being of the institution concerned. From the point of view of regulation, minority educational institutions can be placed into two categories, viz. (1) institutions receiving aid from the state; and (2) institutions not getting aid from the state, each category being further sub-divided according to the nature of the educational institution, namely schools, undergraduate colleges, post-graduate colleges and professional colleges.90 (b) GOVERNMENT GRANTS/RECOGNITION Questions concerning giving of government grants, or according affiliation or recognition, to educational institutions established and managed by the minorities have often been raised before the courts vis-a-vis Art. 30(1). Such questions are of great significance to these institutions. At present, the situation is such that an educational institution cannot possibly hope to survive, and function effectively, without government grants, nor can it confer degrees without affiliation to a University. Although minorities establish and run their educational institutions with a view to educate their children in an atmosphere congenial to the conservation of their language or culture, yet that is not their only aim. They also desire that their students are well-equipped for useful careers in life. The students of unrecognised institutions can neither get admission in institutions of higher learning nor can they enter public service. Therefore, without recognition, a minority run institution cannot fulfil its role effectively and the right conferred by Art. 30(1) would be very much diluted. A meaningful or real exercise of the right under Art. 30(1) must, therefore, mean the right to establish effective educational institutions which may subserve the real needs of the minorities and the scholars who resort to them. This necessarily involves recognition or affiliation of minority institutions, for without this the institutions cannot play their role effectively and the right conferred on the minorities by Art. 30(1) would be denuded of much of its efficacy.91 Art 30(2) debars the state from discriminating against minority institutions in the matter of giving grants. But the question is: can the government impose regulations and conditions on minority institutions for giving them aid or according recognition to them? In Frank Anthony,92 the Court has explained the position thus: "The extent of the right under Art. 30(1) is to be determined, not with reference to any concept of state necessity and general societal interest but with reference to the educational institutions themselves, that is, with reference to the goal of making the institutions effective vehicles of education for the minority community or other persons who resort to them. It follows that regulatory measures which are designed towards the achievement of the goal of making the minority educational institutions effective instruments for imparting the education cannot be considered to impinge upon the rights guaranteed by Art. 30(1) of the Constitution. The question in each case is whether the particular measure is, Page 48 in the ultimate analysis, designed to achieve such goal, without of course nullifying any part of the right of the management in substantial measure." As held in T.M.A. Pai conditions which can normally be permitted to be imposed on the edcational institutions receiving the grant must be related to the proper utilisation of the grant and fulfilment of the objectives of the grant without diluting the minority status of the educational institution.1 In Managing Board, M.T.M. v. State of Bihar, 2 the Supreme Court has emphasized that the right to establish educational institutions of their choice must mean the right to establish real institutions which will effectively serve the needs of their community and the scholars who resort to them. Clarifying the position as regards the question of affiliation of, or grant to, minority institutions, the Court has observed: "There is, no doubt, no such thing as Fundamental Right to recognition by the State but to deny recognition to the educational institutions except upon terms tantamount to the surrender of their constitutional right of administration of the educational institutions of their choice is in truth and in effect to deprive them of their rights under Art. 30(1). We repeat that the legislative power is subject to the Fundamental Rights and the legislature cannot indirectly take away or abridge the Fundamental Rights which it could not do directly ......" Can a State deny recognition to a minority institution on the ground that the State already has more such institutions than required and, therefore, the policy of the government is not to permit the starting of any more such institutions?

We repeat that the legislative power is subject to the Fundamental Rights and the legislature cannot indirectly take away or abridge the Fundamental Rights which it could not do directly ......" Can a State deny recognition to a minority institution on the ground that the State already has more such institutions than required and, therefore, the policy of the government is not to permit the starting of any more such institutions? Can any such policy be regarded as consistent with Art. 30(1)? The State of Karnataka denied recognition to a minority teachers' training college on this basis. The High Court held the denial of recognition not valid. Without specifically deciding the question whether or not the State can have such a policy, the court concluded that the State had no such firm policy as a matter of fact as it had given permission to another similar institution which applied later than the institution in question.3 The same High Court has also held that a minority institution need not take prior permission of the government to be started. Recognition must be given to a minority institution if all the conditions have been satisfied. Recognition cannot be denied on the ground that because of the existence of one school in the locality there is no need for another school. Such a factor is irrelevant so far as a minority institution is concerned.4 In Managing Board, M.T.M. v. State of Bihar, 5 the Supreme Court quashed an order of the Bihar Government refusing recognition to a minority teachers training college. The inspection committee had inspected the college and recommended recognition while the State Government still maintained that the institution did not fulfil all the requisite conditions. The Court thus came to the conclusion that the government's refusal was based on "purely illusory grounds which do not exist", that it was a "colourable exercise of its jurisdiction" and, thus, the order was in violation of Art. 30(1). On the question of government aid to minority institutions, the Supreme Court has observed as follows in St. Stephen's College:6 "The educational institutions are not business houses. They do not generate wealth. They cannot survive without public funds or private aid. It is said that there is also restraint on collection of students fees. With the restraint on collection of fees, the minorities cannot be saddled with the burden of maintaining educational institutions without grant-in-aid. They do not have economic advantages over others. It is not possible to have educational institutions without state aid.. The minorities cannot, therefore, be asked to maintain educational institutions on their own." The rights of the minorities under Art. 30 remain unaffected even after receiving financial assistance from the government. In the following case,7 the government granted recognition with aid to classes VI to VIII in a minority school. Later, the government sought to withdraw aid. The Madras High Court quashed the government order withdrawing aid saying that the minorities cannot be asked tomaintain educational institutions on their own. Every child in India, under Art. 21-A, has a right to free education up to the age of 14 years.8 (c) CONDITIONS FOR GRANTS/RECOGNITION Page 49 The next important question is: What conditions can be imposed on these institutions as a requisite to giving grants, or according affiliation or recognition to them? This has proved to be a complex and controversial problem. These conditions may be of two kinds. One type of conditions may relate to such matters as syllabi, curricula, courses, minimum qualifications of teachers, their age of superannuation, library, conditions concerning sanitary, health and hygiene of students, etc. The underlying purpose of such conditions is to promote educational standards and uniformity and help the institutions concerned achieve efficiency and excellence and are imposed not only in the interest of general secular education but also are conducive to the improvement of minority institutions themselves. Regulatory measures are necessary to maintain the educational character and content of minority institutions.9 Such conditions cannot be regarded as violative of Art. 30(1) and should, therefore, be followed by all educational institutions. The standards of education are not a part of management as such. Therefore, a University can prescribe syllabi for examinations to be followed by every institution subject to any special subjects which a minority institution may seek to teach. Such conditions must, however, satisfy a dual test: (i) these conditions should be reasonable; (ii) these are regulative of the educational character of the institution and are conducive to making it an effective vehicle of education for the minority community or other persons who resort to it. A minority institution being run in unhealthy surroundings, or without qualified teachers, or which does not maintain any fair standard of teaching cannot claim to be recognised.10 Conditions for recognition like adequate space for students can be validly imposed.11 Regulations can also be made providing for inspection or inquiry in respect of school buildings, laboratories, etc., and the mode and manner of inspection and inquiry and furnishing returns, statistics and that information to the competent authority by the school management.12 A school seeking recognition and not aid cannot be obligated not to charge fees from the students, for that would, in effect, make it impossible for the minority institution to carry on.13 The other type of conditions relate to management of the institutions. Not all such conditions can be imposed on minority institutions. Art. 30(1) prima facie confers an unqualified right on the minorities to administer the institutions established by them. But, in practice, such a right cannot be absolute. A right to administer cannot be a right to maladminister. The matter has been succinctly explained by the Supreme Court in In re Kerala Education Bill : "The right to administer cannot obviously include the right to maladminister. The minority cannot surely ask for aid or recognition for an educational institution run by them in unhealthy surroundings.

Therefore, the right of a minority to administer an institution can be subjected to conditions for ensuring orderly, efficient and sound administration,16 but these conditions should not be such as to destroy or take away the right of the minorities to administer educational institutions of their choice. Explaining the concept of reasonableness, the Supreme Court has emphasized that the right under Art. 30 cannot be whittled down by the so-called regulative measures conceived in the interest not of minority educational institutions, but of the public or the nation as a whole. Art. 30(1) would become illusory if every order is held justifiable in public or national interest which, while maintaining the formal character of a minority institution, destroys the power of administration, and may be in its interest as an educational institution. Regulations which may be imposed lawfully as a condition of receiving grant or recognition must be directed to making the institution effective as an educational institution. Regulations may be imposed in the true interests of efficiency of instruction, discipline, health, sanitation, morality, public order and the like. Such regulations are not restrictions on the substance of the right, but secure the proper functioning of the institutions in educational matters.17 In Sidhrajbhai, the Supreme Court refused to accept the contention that public or national interest is the sole measure or test of reasonableness, or that no regulation should be deemed unreasonable unless it is totally destructive or annihilative of the right of the minority to administer educational institution of its choice. This is not permissible. The courts have thus laid down strict parameters within which regulations can be imposed on the minorities' right to administer their institutions. The state enjoys very limited regulatory power as regards minority educational institutions. The state can impose only such regulations on such institutions as would ensure excellence in education. With the enactment of the National Commission for Minority Educational Institutions Act, 2004 as amended in 2006, (Act 18 of 2006), a minority educational institution may seek affiliation to any university of its choice (section 10A) in accordance with the prescribed procedure. The Act does not expressly provide for an appeal from a refusal to grant affiliation but does allow the Commission to enquire into any dispute relating to affiliation and report its finding to the appropriate government for implementation (Section 11 (b). A provision interfering with the minorities' choice of managing body for an institution has been held to violate Art. 30(1).18 For instance, the Gujarat University Act provided that the governing body of every college must include amongst its members a representative of the University nominated by the Vice-Chancellor, representatives of teaching and non-teaching staff and of the college students. In the celebrated St. Xavier's College case,19 the Supreme Court declared the provision as non-applicable to minority institutions because it displaced the management and entrusted it to a different agency; autonomy in administration was lost and new elements in the shape of representatives of different types were brought in. The Court emphasized that while the University could take steps to cure maladministration in a college, the choice of personnel of management was a part of administration which could not be interfered with. Under the Kerala University Act, 1969, governing body was to be constituted for each private college consisting of 11 members of whom 6 were to be nominated by the body which established or maintained that college. The principal, manager, a nominee each of the University and the government and a representative of the teachers of the College, were also to be on the committee. All members were to hold office for four years. It was to be a body corporate and the management of the college was to vest therein. The Supreme Courtdeclared these provisions invalid as they took away from the founders the right to administer their own institution.

(e) APPOINTMENT OF TEACHERS The selection and appointment of teachers, and the head of the institution, is regarded as pre-eminently a function of the administration. As K.K. Mathew, J., has observed supporting the majority view in Ahmedabad St. Xaviers College case:32 "It is upon the principal and teachers of a college that the tone and temper of an educational institution depend. Therefore, the position taken by the Supreme Court is that while a University can prescribe qualifications for the academic staff, the actual selection of teachers must remain in the hands of the administration of the institution and any dilution of this right of the management infringes Art. 30(1). The choice of the person for appointment continues to vest in the managing committee of the minority school and the Board has no further power to interfere with the right of the managing committee of a minority school. This provision ensures that only qualified teachers are appointed in the school. There is no interference with the managerial rights of the institution. The protection given to such institutions by Art. 30(1) is not intended to shield 'commercialised' activities by such institutions which are intended to reap rich dividends by holding education as a façade.4 The Delhi High Court has ruled5 that under Art. 30(1), the right to freely administer educational institutions does not permit the minorities to indulge in commercialisation of education in the garb of constitutional protection. No such institution has the right to maladminister the institution. The court has thus ruled that "on the aspect of commercialisation and exploitation, minority institution would be similarly placed as other institutions". Therefore, it would not be unconstitutional for the government to issue an order which places a restriction on the amount of fee chargeable by an institution, if, on facts, the minority institutions indulge in commercialisation of education and maladministration of the educational institutions.5 The unanimous view of all the judges in T.M.A. Pai was that unaided professional educational institutions (both minority and non-minority) cannot be regulated but no institution should charge capitation fee. Reasonable surplus to meet cost of expansion and augmentation of facilities does not, however, amount to profiteering.6 A Committee has been directed by Islamic Academy of Education to be set up to decide whether the fees proposed by an institute are justified and to approve the fee structure which can be charged by the institute. The fee fixed by the Committee shall be binding for a period of three years, at the end of which period the institute would be at liberty to apply for revision. The decision of the Committee is subject to judicial review.7 (j) MEDIUM OF INSTRUCTION The right of a minority to establish and administer educational institutions of its choice also carries with it the right to impart instruction in its institutions to its children in its own language. The result of reading Arts. 29(1) and 30(1) together is that the minority has the choice of medium of instruction and the power of the state to determine the medium of instruction has, therefore, to yield ground, to the extent it is necessary to give effect to this minority right. A rule prohibiting a minority to use the medium of instruction of its own choice constitutes a restriction of the minority's right to administer its own institutions. To hold otherwise will be to denude Arts. 29(1) and 30(1) of much of their content and the state should, therefore, use its power to determine the medium of instruction in such a manner as to effectuate minority right. Thus, a rule made by the Gujarat University prescribing Gujarati or Hindi as the sole medium of instruction and examination in its affiliated colleges was held to infringe the right of the Anglo-Indians under Art. 30(1) and 30(2) insofar as their mothertongue was English8 and they would be prevented thereby from teaching through the English medium in their own institutions. The most significant case on this point is the Panjabi University case.9 By a notification, the Punjab Government compulsorily affiliated certain colleges to the Punjabi Universitywhich prescribed Punjabi in the Gurmukhi script as the sole and exclusive medium of instruction and examination for certain courses. The Supreme Court declared that it violated the right of the Arya Samajists to use their own script in the colleges run by them and compulsorily affiliated to the University. The Court emphasized that if the University compulsorily affiliates minority colleges to itself and prescribes the medium of instruction and examination to be in a language which is not their mother tongue, or requires examination to be taken in a script which is not their own, then it would interfere with their Fundamental Rights. No linguistic minority can, of course, insist that a University must conduct its examinations in the language or script of the minority, but, at the same time, the University also cannot force the minority institutions to compulsorily affiliate themselves to it and impose on them a medium of instruction which is different from the minority's language or script. The State has to harmonise its power to prescribe the medium of instruction with the rights of the religious or linguistic minorities to have the medium of instruction and script of their own choice. The State can therefore either provide for instruction in the media of these Page 63 minorities, or allow their institutions to get affiliated to such other Universities outside the State as have the same media of instruction as the minority institutions. The Supreme Court observed in this connection:10 "The University by adopting Punjabi as the sole or exclusive medium for the colleges affiliated to the University...acted in excess of the power conferred on it. While the University can prescribe Punjabi as a medium of instruction it cannot prescribe it as the exclusive medium nor compel affiliated colleges established and administered by linguistic or religious minorities or by a section of the citizens who wish to conserve their language, script or culture, to teach in Punjabi or take examinations in that language with Gurmukhi script. The University Act having compulsorily affiliated these Colleges must of necessity cater to their needs and allow them to administer their institutions in their own way and impart instructions in the medium and write examination in their own script..." The Supreme Court has stated11 that while a State is free to provide for the education of the majority in the regional medium, it is subject to the restrictions contained in Arts. 25 to 30. The State cannot provide for imparting education in a medium of instruction in a language and script which stifles the language or script of any section of the citizens. Such a course will trespass on the rights of those sections of the citizens which have a distinct language or script and which they have a right to conserve through educational institutions of their own.

An order was issued dated July 20, 1982 by the Government of Karnataka making the study of Kannada language as a compulsory subject for the children belonging to linguistic minority groups in the State from the first year of the primary school. The Government order also compelled the students joining high schools to take Kannada as the sole first language and also compelled the high schools established by the linguistic minorities to introduce Kannada as the sole first language in the secondary schools. The Karnataka High Court ruled in General Secretary, Linguistic Minorities Protection Committee v. State of Karnataka, 12 by a majority of 2 : 1, that the Government Order was violative of Arts. 14, 29(1) and 30(1). This view was reiterated recently by the Karnataka High Court13 which relied on the provisions of Art. 350-A of the Constitution to hold that in fact an obligation was cast upon every State and every local authority within the State to provide adequate facilities for instruction in the mother tongue at the primary stage of education to children belonging to linguistic minority groups. (k) ACQUISITION OF PROPERTY OF A MINORITY EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION The Constitution Forty-fourth Amendment enacted in 1978 added Art. 30(1A) to the Constitution which runs as follows: "In making any law providing for the compulsory acquisition of any property of an educational institution established and administered by a minority, referred to in clause (1), the State shall ensure that the amount fixed by or determined under such law, for the acquisition of such property is such as would not restrict or abrogate the right guaranteed under that clause." Article 30(1A) became necessary because Art. 31 was being abrogated from the Constitution.14 The above clause previously existed as a proviso to Art. 31(2). The State has a right to acquire property belonging to a minority institution. This provision seeks to protect minority rights somewhat in this regard but the actual implications of Art. 30(1A) are not clear. Does it mean that the State is to give adequate compensation for the property acquired? The Supreme Court has now commented on the scope of Art. 30(1A) in Society of St. Joseph's College v. Union of India.15 The Court has pointed out that Art. 30(1A) has been introduced in the Constitution because Parliament in its constituent capacity16 apprehended that minority educational institutions could be compelled to close down or curtail their activities by the expedient of acquiring their property and paying them inadequate amounts as compensation. Page 64 The Court has emphasized that Art. 30(1A) requires that Parliament or a State Legislature, as the case may be, ought to make a specific law to provide for the compulsory acquisition of the property belonging to minority educational institutions. The provisions of this law should be such as would ensure that the amount payable to the educational institution for the acquisition of its property will not in any manner impair the functioning of the educational institution. The general law viz.the Land Acquisition Act is not adequate for the purpose of acquiring the property of minority educational institutions. INTRODUCTORY The Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978, constitutes a watershed in the evolution of the Fundamental Right to Property in India. Truly speaking, this Amendment signifies demise of the Fundamental Right to Property. Before 1978, there existed mainly two Articles to protect private property, viz., Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31. Both these constitutional provisions were repealed by this Constitutional Amendment, and, thus, left private property defenceless against legislative onslaught. The present Chapter focusses on Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31 as they existed before 1978. This Chapter is thus primarily of historical value and it puts the continual devaluation of the right to property since the inauguration of the Constitution in a historical perspective. The present position in the area of property rights is discussed in the following Chapter. It may not be out of place to mention that the natural law jurists regarded protection to property, alongwith life and liberty of a person, as being of paramount necessity in a free society.

present position in the area of property rights is discussed in the following Chapter. It may not be out of place to mention that the natural law jurists regarded protection to property, alongwith life and liberty of a person, as being of paramount necessity in a free society. It is for this reason that the U.S. Constitution in the V Amendment ordains : "No person can be deprived of his life, liberty or property without due process of life". In India, on the other hand, the policy-makers under the impact of the socialist philosophy started devaluing the institution of private property almost from the very day the Constitution came into force. In Independent India, no Fundamental Right has caused so much trouble, and has given rise to so much litigation between the government and the citizen, as the right to property. While the Supreme Court has sought to expand the scope and ambit of many Fundamental Rights, including the right to property, this right has been progressively curtailed through constitutional amendments.1 Although, originally, the Constitution contained adequate provisions to protect private property, and although the Supreme Court sought to interpret these constitutional provisions liberally in favour of the protection to the institution of property, the fact remains that the right to property has practically ceased to exist in India. Some of the locusclassicus cases in Indian Constitutional Law have arisen in the area of property rights. The reason for such a development is that the Central and State Governments have enacted massive legislation to regulate property rights. First, the government undertook to reconstruct the agrarian economy, inter alia, by trying to confer rights of property on the tiller, abolition of zamindaris, giving security of tenure to tenants, fixing a ceiling on personal holding of agricultural land and redistributing the surplus land among the landless. Secondly, in the area of urban property, measures have been initiated to provide housing to the people, clearance of the slums and town planning, control rents, acquire property and impose a ceiling on urban land ownership, etc. Thirdly, the government has undertaken regulation of private enterprise and nationalization of some commercial undertakings. These various legislative measures have been undertaken to effectuate some of the Directive Principles of Page 72 State Policy2 as well as to usher in the accepted goal of establishing a socialist pattern of society in India.3 These multifarious measures concerning property have led to the uprooting of vested interests and property rights on a large scale. Consequently, in a large number of cases, legislation came to be challenged before the courts. The most significant controversy in these cases was the question of payment of compensation for the property right acquired. Important constitutional battles have been fought around this question and the Constitution has been amended several times to get over some inconvenient judicial rulings.4 So much bitterness has been generated in relation to property rights that while, at times, on the one hand, demands have been made to abolish the Fundamental Right to property, on the other hand, it has been asserted that property rights are essential for the survival of a democratic society, and that the dilution of property right has defaced and defiled the Constitution.5 Two trends, rather inconsistent, hold out in this area. On the one hand, generally speaking, the Courts have leaned towards protecting property rights and payment of adequate compensation for property rights acquired by the state. On the other hand, the state has progressively, by amending the Constitution, reduced the occasions when compensation is payable for disturbance of property rights and has sought to minimise intervention by the courts in this area. The action and interaction thus produced between legislative and judicial processes form an extremely fascinating Chapter in India's constitutional development, so much so that the enactment of the First and the Seventeenth Amendments curtailing property rights even led to the raising of the critical question of the amendability of the Constitution itself.6 EMINENT DOMAIN It is regarded as an inherent right of the state, an essential incident of its sovereignty, to take private property for public use. This power, known as Eminent Domain, depends on the superior domain of the state over all property within its boundaries; it is supposed to be based upon an implied reservation by the state that property acquired by its citizens under its protection may be taken, or its use controlled, for public benefit irrespective of the wishes of the owner. An incident of this power, however, is that property shall not be taken for public use without just compensation.7 The power of eminent domain has been described by the U.S. Supreme Court thus: when public need requires acquisition of property, the need is not to be denied because of an individual's unwillingness to sell. When the need arises, individuals may be required to relinquish ownership of property so long as they are given just compensation which the Constitution requires.8 The power of eminent domain can, therefore, be defined as the power of the state to take property for public use, without the owner's consent upon making just compensation to him. The two essential ingredients of eminent domain are: (1) property is taken for public use; (2) compensation is paid for the property taken. In the U.S.A., compensation is payable for 'taking' the property9 which does not necessarily mean vesting of possession or ownership in the government. If regulation of a property right goes too far, it may be recognised by the courts as 'taking' and compensation may become payable.

observed by Justice Holmes:10 "The general rule at least is that while property may be regulated to certain extent, if regulation goes too far it will be recognised as a taking." Thus, in United States v. Causley, 11 it was held that the respondent's property was 'taken' by regular and frequent flights of army and navy aircraft over his land at low attitude which did depress the value of the land.12 The question of compensation is justiciable as it is a question of a constitutional right. In Britain, on the other hand, the rule is that, unless Parliament explicitly provides to the contrary, it must be assumed that any legislation authorising compulsory acquisition of property intends to provide full compensation.13 The Indian version of eminent domain is to be found in entry 42, List III, which says "acquisition or requisitioning of property".14 In Kameshwar,15 the Supreme Court emphasized that the power to acquire Page 73 property compulsorily meant power to take property for a public purpose and for compensation. The Court defined eminent domain as "the power of the sovereign to take property for public use without the owner's consent upon making just compensation". The ideas of 'public purpose' and 'compensation' are thus inherent in entry 42.16 To start with, the Constitution had Art. 19(1)(f) and Art. 31 to protect property rights. In course of time, Art. 31 came to be modified drastically through several constitutional amendments. Ultimately, in 1978, by the Constitution 44th Amendment, Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31 were abrogated. Although these provisions have lost their relevance after the 44th Amendment, nevertheless, a brief discussion on these provisions is included here in view of the importance of the subject. This discussion is necessary to understand the genesis, and appreciate the implication, of the existing provisions relating to property. Also, since the 44th Amendment is not retrospective,17 and Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31 have been deleted with effect from June 20, 1979, all laws enacted earlier are still subject to these Articles. Arts. 31A, 31B and 31C as well as Art. 300A are the existing constitutional provisions concerning private property. Art. 300A has been added by the 44th Amendment.18 B. ARTICLES 19(1)(f) AND 19(5) Until 1978, Art. 19(1)(f) existed in the Constitution which gave a modicum of protection to private property. Art. 19(1)(f) was repealed by the 44th Constitution Amendment and Art. 300A was introduced in the Constitution in its place. This move has very much diluted constitutional protection to the institution of private property in India. Although repealed, the following discussion on Art. 19(1)(f) has been included here for its historical interest. Article 19(1) (f) guaranteed to the Indian citizens a right to acquire, hold and dispose of property. Art. 19(5), however, permitted the state to impose by law reasonable restrictions on this right in the interests of the general public or for the protection of the interests of any Scheduled Tribe. A few words in these provisions need some explanation. 'To acquire' means, in common parlance, to become the owner of. Unless there is a transfer of property to another, or vesting and divesting of property, there cannot be any acquisition of property. The acquisition must, however, be through legal means. Thus, a thief who steals property, or a usurper of another's property, or one who cannot justify in law his acquisition, would not be protected by Art. 19(1)(f). The term 'to hold' means to possess the property and enjoy the benefits which are ordinarily attached to its ownership including its management. 'To dispose of' means to transfer, assign or sell the property. The power to dispose of property is a necessary concomitant of the power to hold property, for the latter would be meaningless without the former. (a) PROPERTY What is the meaning of the term 'property'? Generally speaking, the word 'property' has a very broad connotation, and is indicative and descriptive of every possible interest which a person can have. Not only the thing which is the subject-matter of ownership, but even dominium, or the right of ownership, possession, etc., fall within the scope of this term. To begin with, the courts sought to interpret the term 'property' in Art. 19(1)(f) somewhat restrictively in order to limit the guarantee thereunder. In Chiranjit Lal v. India, 19 the right of voting enjoyed by the shareholders of a company, or their right to select the directors, or their right to pass resolutions, or institute winding up proceedings, were held to be not 'property'. A share in a joint stock company was 'property' but these rights or privileges were appurtenant to, or flowed from, the ownership of the share, and "by themselves and taken independently they cannot be reckoned as property capable of being acquired, held or disposed of." These rights were characterised as 'personal rights'. It was stated that for purposes of Art. 19(1)(f), property was that which could by itself be acquired, disposed of or taken possession of. This restrictive view would appear to strike at the root of the protection of incorporeal rights. Further, the right Page 74 of management of a company was ordinarily vested in the shareholders; and as management was an important incident of holding property, the right to hold property was affected if right of management was affected. Further, by regulating the right of management, the right to the property, i.e., the share, was also affected from another point of view, viz., undoubtedly, the value of the share must fall, and so the matter could still be brought under Art. 19(1)(f). In State of West Bengal v. Subodh, Gopal,20 Sastri, C.J., propounded the theory that Art. 19(1)(f) dealt only with the natural rights inherent in a citizen to acquire, hold, dispose of property in the abstract without any reference to any particular property; that Art. 19(1)(f) concerned only with the abstract right and capacity to hold, acquire and dispose of property and had no relation to concrete property rights.

In other words, the Article forbade the state to deny to particular individuals, or classes of individuals, the right to own property, but did not protect a citizen's interest in a particular piece of property or business from state interference. The reasonableness of restrictions placed upon him could, therefore, be judged under Art. 19(1)(f). The Court stated, "To suggest that abstract rights of a citizen in property cannot be infringed by the State but his concrete rights can be, is to deprive Art. 19(1)(f) of its real content."34 In M.M. Union of India, 35 it was held that 'property' within the meaning of Art. 19(1)(f) [as well as Art. 31(2)]36 comprised every form of property, tangible or intangible, including debts and choses in action. (b) RESTRICTIONS The expression "interest of general public" in Art. 19(5) was held synonymous with "public interest". It did not mean the interest of the public of the whole of India; it meant interest of a "section of the public" and, thus, a law affecting a limited class of persons in a local area could well be legislation in the public interest. The removal of a serious abuse, grievance, discontent or hardship of a particular class was a matter of public interest for it was not in public interest to allow any class of people to labour under some grievance.37 The term 'public interest' was very broad and was held to include public order, public health, morality, etc. Whether a piece of legislation was in public interest or not was a justiciable matter. A law designed to abate a grave nuisance and thus protect public health,38 or a law to protect the weaker sections of the public, especially members of low castes,39 was held to be in public interest.

The right of pre-emption of urban property by vicinage was held to be unreasonable because it raised litigation and was not in the interest of the general public. The real reason behind the law which was introduced during the Muslim rule, was to prevent strangers, i.e., people belonging to different religion, race or caste, from acquiring property. Such a division of society into groups, and exclusion of strangers from any locality, could not be considered reasonable under Art. 19(5). The right of pre-emption in favour of a co-sharer was held to be valid as introduction of a stranger would make management of the property extremely difficult and would destroy the benefit of ownership in common. Speaking generally, the courts did not take kindly to conferment of absolute discretion on administrative officers uncabined by any procedural safeguards. At the minimum, right of hearing to the party affected was insisted upon as an essential safeguard,74 but, at times, courts insisted that the statute should incorporate some substantive norms to regulate administrative discretion to interfere with property. Under a law, the Deputy Commissioner (acting as the Court of Wards) could, in his subjective determination, assume the superintendence of property of a landlord who habitually infringed the rights of the tenants. The discretion so conferred could not be called into question in any civil court. The law was held unreasonable for it deprived the landlord of his property for an indefinite period merely on the subjective satisfaction of an executive officer without giving him a right to take recourse to a civil court.75 On the other hand, a legal provision empowering the municipal commissioner to make a clearance order was held valid because the tenants affected by such an order had a right to file objections against the order, and they could also appeal to a civil court.76 Page 78 An administrative order imposing a cut in superannuation pension of a civil servant without giving him an opportunity to show cause against it was held not valid.77 A law authorising the reclamation officer to declare any land as kans infested and to enter and start reclamation operations therein without giving any opportunity to the landowner to show that his land was not really so infested was held to be void because the absence of the right of hearing to the landowner made the provision arbitrary.78 Power given to the Commissioner to take over the administration of a religious endowment for five years, was held invalid as 'extremely drastic in character', because no access was allowed to the court to set aside the order. But a provision authorising the Commissioner to pass any order which he deemed necessary to ensure that an endowment was properly administered and its income duly appropriated for the purpose for which it was founded, was held not unreasonable, for some amount of control over the due administration of the endowments was certainly necessary in the interests of the public.79 Similarly, power given to the Commissioner to make an inquiry into or try the charges against the mahant and order his removal if such charges were established had been held to be valid as it was subject to a few safeguards: (1) proceedings before the Commissioner were quasi-judicial; (2) order of removal could be challenged in a court; (3) an appeal could be taken to the High Court, and (4) the grounds for removal were specified in the Act.80 An Act authorised an administrative officer to evict a person occupying any government premises if the officer was satisfied that he was in unauthorised occupation of the premises. Before making the order, the affected person was to be given an adequate opportunity to tender an explanation and produce evidence in his support. He could then appeal to the State Government against the order, but could have no recourse to the courts. The Act was held valid because of adequate procedural safeguards contained therein.81 A law making the right of disposal of property subject to the uncontrolled discretion of an administrative officer was regarded as bad. The most fundamental element of ownership being the right to alienate. Therefore, to be valid, the law should contain guidelines for the exercise of the administrative discretion.82 A law conferred on administrative authorities the power to acquire fisheries as well as the power to decide the amount of compensation payable for the property acquired. The authorities were to act in a quasi-judicial manner in deciding the amount of compensation, but the jurisdiction of the courts was excluded in this matter. The law was found to be not unreasonable because the concerned authorities were still to be subject to the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court and the High Courts under the relevant constitutional provisions.83 A law authorised the State Government to acquire any movable property if it considered 'necessary and expedient' to do so and pay such compensation as it might determine. Under the Act, the petitioners were allotted a piece of land which was nearly half of what had been taken away from them, and they were also required to pay a sum of money as increment in the value of land. The petitioner challenged the Act inter alia on the ground that it vested arbitrary powers in administrative officers and, thus, infringed Art. 19(1)(f). The Supreme Court, however, upheld the Act as valid for it contained elaborate substantive and procedural provisions for formulation of the plans. The Act thus imposed only reasonable restrictions on the right to hold and enjoy property.85 Under an Act, when government auctioned land and full consideration was not paid for it, unpaid money constituted the first charge on the auctioned property.

ARTICLE 31 Article 31(1) laid down that no person could be deprived of his property without the authority of law. This provision has been repealed through the 44th Amendment but it re-appears as Art. 300A noted later in the next Chapter.95 Therefore, nothing need be said on Art. 31(1) at this place. Article 31(2) has also been repealed now but discussion thereon has been included here partly for its historical importance; partly to illustrate judicial activism and creativity in interpreting the Constitution; partly because of a kind of tussle between the Supreme Court and Parliament, as the constituent body, on the question of compensation for property acquired, and partly because some of the ideas developed under Art. 31(2) might come to be incorporated by the courts in the interpretation of Art. 300A. Article 31(2) as it stood before its abrogation in 1978 ran as follows: "No property shall be compulsorily acquired or requisitioned save for a public purpose and save by authority of a law which provides for acquisition or requisitioning of the property for an amount which may be fixed by such law or which may be determined in accordance with such principles and given in such manner as may be specified in such law, and no such law shall be called in question in any court on the ground that the amount so fixed or determined is not adequate or that the whole or any part of such amount is to be given otherwise than in cash." This was an amended version of the original Art. 31(2) as it appeared in the Constitution in 1950. The above clause was substituted by the XXV Amendment of the Constitution in 1971.1 The process of amending Art. 31(2) from 1950 to 1978 is discussed below. The original Art. 31(2) ran as follows: "No property... shall be taken possession of or acquired for public purposes under any law authorising the taking of such possession or such acquisition, unless the law provides for compensation for the property taken possession of or acquired and either fixes the amount of compensation, or specifies the principles on which, and the manner in which, the compensation is to be determined and given". Four concepts were involved in Art. 31(2): (1) Property; (2) Compulsory acquisition and requisitioning by the State; (3) amount; and (4) public purpose. Each of these concepts is discussed below. (i) PROPERTY The term 'property' was used in this provision not in a narrow, but in a comprehensive, sense. "Any legal right which can be enforced through a court is a right in the nature of property within the meaning of Art. 31(2)." Even an actionable claim could be regarded as property.2 Page 81 (ii) COMPULSORY ACQUISITION OR REQUISITIONING These words did not occur in the Article originally. To begin with, in their place, the words in the Article were "taken possession of or acquired". The Supreme Court giving a liberal interpretation to these words held that they meant the same things as 'deprivation' in Art. 31(1). The result of this judicial approach was that abridgement of the incidents of property might amount to 'deprivation' for which compensation became payable even though the state might not have acquired the same. In State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal, 3 the Supreme Court stressed that Arts. 31(1) and 31(2) were not mutually exclusive in scope and content; that they should be read together and understood as dealing with the same subject-matter, viz., protection of private property, and that 'deprivation' contemplated in Art. 31(1) was nothing else but "acquisition or taking possession" of property referred to in Art. 31(2). Thus, curtailment of an incident of estate was held to fall within Arts. 31(1) and (2).4 In Dwarkadas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co .,5 the Central Government promulgated an ordinance vesting the assets and management of the Sholapur Mills in government-appointed directors. This step was taken to avert closure of the mills due to mismanagement. The Supreme Court declared the law bad because vesting of Company's property in government nominees, who functioned under government orders, meant that the company's property had in effect been taken possession of by the State, depriving the company of it, without compensation. The Court rejected the argument that "taking possession of" in Art. 31(2) meant that Art. 31(2) would not apply unless the property was vested in the State for State purpose. The Court ruled that compensation was payable no matter by what process a person was deprived of his property, or what use the State made of it. In Saghir Ahmad v. State of Uttar Pradesh, 6 the Court held that depriving a person of his interest in a commercial undertaking attracted Art. 31(2) although the State did not acquire or take possession of the same. Taking of possession of kans infested land temporarily by the state for purposes of reclaiming it was held to amount to taking possession of land within the meaning of Art.

Saghir Ahmad v. State of Uttar Pradesh, 6 the Court held that depriving a person of his interest in a commercial undertaking attracted Art. 31(2) although the State did not acquire or take possession of the same. Taking of possession of kans infested land temporarily by the state for purposes of reclaiming it was held to amount to taking possession of land within the meaning of Art. 31(2) for which compensation was payable.7 These cases established the proposition that the words 'acquisition' or 'taking possession' in Art. 31(2) were synonymous with 'deprivation' in Art. 31(1). Therefore, if the right to enjoy property was impaired, or if any incident of property was abridged or diluted, or if the value of the property was affected, by any law, compensation became payable irrespective of the fact whether the state was acquiring the property for public use or just seeking to regulate it. The crucial question, however, in any such situation was whether the 'deprivation' resulting from government regulation was 'substantial' or not. This was a question for the courts to decide and, thus, the courts had effective power to draw a balance between State 'regulation' and private property.8 Had Art. 31(2) stood as it was at this time, it might have been possible for the courts in India to create a body of rules, on the basis of what constituted "substantial deprivation", to lay down in what kinds of deprivation of property should compensation be payable. The position might have been somewhat akin to the position in the U.S.A., discussed earlier. But that was not to be as Art. 31(2) was drastically amended by the Fourth Constitutional Amendment which caused a change of great consequence as it took such matters out of the area of compensation and restricted its payment only to situations when the state took possession or acquired the ownership of property. It appeared to the Central Government that the judicial approach that compensation was payable even when a mere 'regulatory' law curtailed the right to property, too much restricted the capacity of the State to regulate economic affairs. To get over this difficulty, Art. 31(2) was amended in 1955 by the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act by which the words 'acquisition and taking possession of' were replaced by the expression "compulsorily acquired or requisitioned". To explain these terms, a new provision, Art. 31(2A), was added. Article 31(2A) said that unless a law provided for the transfer of ownership or right to possession of any property to the State, or to a State-owned or controlled corporation, "it shall not be deemed to provide for the compulsory acquisition or requisitioning of property, notwithstanding that it deprives any person of his property." Page 82 Compensation was not payable for mere deprivation of property or extinction of ownership therein.9 Where no transfer of ownership or possession of property was effected, Art. 31(2) could not apply. Art. 31(2), therefore, held non-applicable when there was a mere extinction of a right arising under a contract.10 The purpose of these amendments was to restate more precisely the State's power of compulsory acquisition and requisitioning of property and to distinguish it from deprivation of property by the operation of regulatory or prohibitory laws. The Fourth Amendment made it clear that it is only in the first situation, and not for the second, that compensation was payable. To justify the necessity of the Fourth Amendment, so far as Art. 31(2) was concerned, an argument advanced by the Central Government was that the judiciary had held that compensation was payable for "any deprivation of property', even by a purely regulatory law. The actual position, however, was somewhat different from that which this statement sought to make out. What the Supreme Court had actually held was that compensation was payable in case of "substantial dispossession" or "serious impairment" of the property right. The Central Government was not satisfied with this judicial approach and wanted to restrict payment of compensation only when there was acquisition involving transfer of ownership, or requisitioning involving transfer of the right of possession to the state, and not for mere deprivation of property right. The right to private property thus became very much circumscribed as a result of the Fourth Amendment. As a result of this new provision, the rulings in cases like Sholapur Mills or Saghir Ahmad could no longer be invoked. Thus, deprivation of property now became divided into two categories: (1) compulsory acquisition and requisitioning of property by the State for a public purpose; (2) deprivation of property without the ownership or right of possession being transferred to the state. The new Art. 31(2) applied to the former, but not to the latter, situation. Thus, compensation was payable by the state in case (1), and not in case (2), in which case only a valid law was needed. Consequently, a provision imposing certain restrictions on sale of lands by an occupant and declaring that a sale contravening these conditions would be invalid and the land forfeited to the government was held to amount to 'deprivation' under Art. 31(1) and not 'acquisition' under Art. 31(2).11 A law authorising State transport authority to cancel existing permits of a person carrying on his transport business, and issuing the same to the State transport undertaking was held not to involve the transfer of undertaking of the quondam permit holder to the new entrant.12 This overruled Saghir Ahmad on this point. Land of some persons had been sold by public auction for non-payment of revenue during the struggle for independence. A State law re-transferred this land from the present holder to the original owners. It was held that transfer of land from one person to another, without the State itself getting any interest therein, was 'deprivation' under Art. 31(1) and not 'compulsory acquisition or requisition' under Art.

State law re-transferred this land from the present holder to the original owners. It was held that transfer of land from one person to another, without the State itself getting any interest therein, was 'deprivation' under Art. 31(1) and not 'compulsory acquisition or requisition' under Art. 31(2).13 (iii) AMOUNT After the inauguration of the Constitution, for a number of years, the question of quantum of compensation payable by the government for private property acquired by it became a very controversial matter. Before the year 1971, the word 'compensation' occurred in Art. 31(2). Since the inauguration of the Constitution, the Courts had been faced with two critical questions: (1) What was the significance of the word 'compensation'? (2) What should be the role of the courts in this respect? The developments in this area could be discussed in three stages as follows. (a) BEFORE 1955 As Art. 31(2) originally stood in the Constitution, the word 'compensation' used therein was not qualified by any adjective like 'just' or 'adequate', unlike the U.S. Constitution where the V Amendment requires the payment of 'just compensation' when the Federal Government takes private property for public use. Page 83 Nevertheless, the Supreme Court displaying a creative stance, took the position that the omission of the word 'just' or 'adequate' before 'compensation' was immaterial, and that the word 'compensation' standing alone, by itself, meant 'just' and 'equivalent' compensation for the interest in property acquired. This approach was adopted in a number of cases by the Supreme Court. The foremost case advocating this judicial point of view was State of West Bengal v. Bella Banerji.14 The West Bengal Legislature enacted a law to acquire land for settling refugees from East Pakistan. It provided that the 'compensation' to the owners of the land acquired was not to exceed the market value of the property as on December 31, 1946. The law was held to be unconstitutional on the ground that the 'compensation' bore no relation to the market value of the land on the date of acquisition. Land could be acquired many years after the prescribed date, but compensation for it was still to be assessed with reference to the prescribed date and not the date of acquisition, which was objectionable. The Court emphasized that 'compensation' meant 'just equivalent' of the property acquired and that it was a justiciable matter which the courts could adjudicate upon.15 The same principle was applied by the Supreme Court in State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar .16 A Madras law providing for payment of compensation for acquisition of lignite-bearing land on the basis of the land value on April 28, 1947, irrespective of the date of acquisition was held invalid. The Court held that freezing land value with reference to a specified date denied the landowners increment in land value since the specified date till the date of acquisition and this did not amount to 'compensation' as envisaged in Art. 31(2).17 Thus, before 1955, the Supreme Court had taken the position that a statute was liable to be struck down as infringing Art. 31(2) on the ground that 'compensation' provided by it was inadequate and that 'compensation' ought to be the just equivalent of the property of which a person was deprived and that 'adequacy' of 'compensation' was a justiciable matter. An interesting point to note in this connection is that while in 1950, in Gopalan,18 the Supreme Court had adopted a strictly literal interpretation of Art. 21 in a matter dealing with personal liberty, the Court adopted a liberal and purposive interpretation of Art. 31(2) dealing with the question of property. This dichotomy of judicial attitudes towards the two constitutional provisions indicates that, at this time, the Court attached far more importance to property rights than to right of person and, therefore, it was prepared to give greater protection to property than to person. (b) FROM 1955 TO 1971 The Central Government became uneasy at the judicial insistence on payment of full market value for the property acquired, as it thought that it would place an onerous burden on the country's slender resources and would throw out of gear the envisaged socioeconomic programme involving reconstruction of property relations, especially, in the area of agricultural land. Therefore, to get over this hurdle, the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955, was undertaken.19 The Fourth Amendment amended Art. 31(2) with a view to make the question of 'adequacy' of compensation as 'non-justiciable'. The courts were now debarred from going into the question whether the quantum of compensation provided by a law for property being acquired or requisitioned by the state was 'adequate' or not. Art. 31(2) at this time ran as follows: "(2) No property shall be compulsorily acquired or requisitioned save for a public purpose and save by authority of a law which provides for compensation for the property so acquired or requisitioned and either fixes the amount of the compensation or specifies the principles on which, and the manner in which, the compensation is to be determined and given; and no such law shall be questioned in any court on the ground that the compensation provided by that law is not adequate. (2A) Where a law does not provide for the transfer of the ownership or right to possession of any property to the State or to a corporation owned or controlled by the State, it shall not be deemed to provide for the compulsory acquisition or requisitioning of property, notwithstanding that it deprives any person of his property". The Supreme Court has explained the purport of the Fourth Amendment as follows:20 "After the 4th Amendment, the word "compensation", could not mean a full and fair money equivalent, for if it did, the law would have remained unchanged and the 4th Amendment would have failed of its purpose.

excluding a Page 84 challenge on the ground that the compensation provided by the law was not adequate, the 4th Amendment removed the restriction on legislative power in the sense that for the law to be valid it was no longer obligatory to provide for the payment of full and fair money equivalent." According to the sponsors of the Fourth Amendment, its purpose was to bring the Constitution in accord with the intentions of the framers of the Constitution, that the quantum of compensation ought to be decided finally by the Legislature. Pandit Nehru said in the Lok Sabha:21 "It was obvious that those who framed the Constitution failed to give expression to their wishes accurately and precisely and thereby the Supreme Court and some other Courts have interpreted it in a different way." It was thus claimed that the Amendment was designed to word the Constitution precisely in accordance with what the framers of the Constitution at that time had envisaged, meant and openly said. It is true that Nehru and a few others in the Constituent Assembly had thought that the original article 31(2) made the Legislature the final arbiter of the quantum of compensation which ought not to be challengeable in the court except when there was fraud on the Constitution or a fraudulent exercise of the power so given. To the extent the Fourth Amendment made compensation non-justiciable, it could be said to accord with the intentions of some of the constitution-makers. But the Fourth Amendment did not stop at this. It had a much broader coverage. Arts. 31A and 31B22 were also added. These provisions were much more extensive in scope than what the framers of the Constitution had ever thought of. The Constitution was amended to serve certain purposes which the constitution-makers had never dreamt of. As for example, social welfare legislation and regulatory legislation were only recently thought of. The Amendment in effect reconstituted original Art. 31 in a very fundamental manner. The IVth Amendment however failed to exclude the courts completely from the area of 'compensation'. In 1961, in Burrakur Coal Co. v. Union of India, 23 a law acquiring coal-bearing land provided compensation only for the land but not for the minerals therein. The Supreme Court refused to hold the law bad arguing that the question of non-payment of compensation for minerals referred to adequacy of compensation in which the court could not go. This pronouncement may be regarded as being in tune with what the Fourth Amendment was designed to envisage. But, thereafter, from 1965 onwards the judicial view underwent a change. The Supreme Court again started showing some activism on the question of compensation. In its bid to break through the shackles imposed by Art. 31(2) after the IV Amendment, and provide some protection to private property, the Supreme Court took the view in Vajravelu v. Special Deputy Collector, 24 that the amended Art. 31(2) still retained the word 'compensation' which meant that the meaning of the expression 'compensation' as given to it in Bella Banerjee had been accepted. Therefore, a law for acquisition or requisitioning should still provide for a 'just compensation' for what the owner was being deprived of. Although, under the amended Art. 31(2), the principles prescribing the 'just equivalent' could not be questioned on the ground of inadequacy yet, if the principles were not relevant to the value of the property acquired at the time of acquisition, then the courts could intervene and scrutinise the validity of the principles. The Supreme Court was careful to emphasize that this formulation had reference not to the 'adequacy' of 'compensation' but to 'no compensation' at all. Thus, "if the compensation is illusory, or if the principles prescribed are irrelevant to the value of the property at or about the time of its acquisition" then it could be said that the legislature had played a fraud on the Constitution. The compensation given might not be adequate, yet it should not be so little as to constitute a fraud on the legislative power. If, however, the principles to determine compensation were relevant to the fixing of "compensation", and were not arbitrary, then the 'adequacy' of the resultant product could not be questioned in a court. The Supreme Court thus asserted a power of judicial review of compensation in certain situations. In effect, however, under the new norm, compensation could be less than the market value of the property acquired. The new formula was somewhat different from, rather less rigorous than, the Bella Banerjee view, but still the courts claimed a foothold in the area of compensation and did not completely vacate the field. This ruling was an attempt on the part of the Supreme Court to break through the restrictive Art. 31(2). The government could not escape by providing shadowy compensation merely to fulfil the letter of the law. This shows that Page 85 the Court was anxious to extend some protection to property rights. In pursuance of this judicial approach, in 1967, the Supreme Courtdeclared invalid the Metal Corporation of India (Acquisition of Undertaking) Act, 1965. The Act aquiring the corporation laid down two principles for valuation of its assets: (1) the unused equipment in good condition was to be valued at the actual cost of its acquisition to the company; (2) the used equipment was to be valued at the written down value determined in accordance with the principles contained in the Income-tax Act. The Court held these principles not 'relevant' to the fixing of compensation for the machinery at the time of its acquisition.

Supreme Court, however, insisted that if the principles were relevant to the fixing of 'compensation', and were not 'arbitrary', then the 'adequacy' of the resultant product could not be questioned in a court.25 The judicial view appeared to have undergone some change in State of Gujarat v. Shantilal .26 Under a Town Planning Act, a notification expressing intention of the government to acquire a plot of land was issued in 1942; the actual acquisition took place in 1957, and compensation was assessed with reference to its market value in 1942. This was challenged on the ground that the value of the land determined with reference to a date far removed from the date of actual acquisition could not be regarded as the 'just equivalent' of the property acquired. The Supreme Courtupheld the Act because the principle for determining 'compensation' laid down therein could not be said to be 'irrelevant' to the determination of 'compensation', nor could the 'compensation' be regarded as 'illusory'. The Court emphasized that it could not go into the question of 'adequacy' of compensation unless the legislature abused its legislative power and called something as 'compensation' which was not a recompense at all or was 'illusory'. Principles to determine compensation could be challenged on the ground that "they are irrelevant to the determination of compensation," but not on the plea that the compensation being awarded was not "just or fair compensation". The Metal Corporation case was overruled with the remark that there "the principles were not irrelevant to the determination of compensation and the compensation was not illusory." The dichotomy of the judicial views expressed in Metal Corporation and Shantilal was this: in the former case, the Court laid emphasis on 'just equivalent' of the property acquired, and, therefore, if the law in question specified principles for fixing 'compensation' for the property acquired to achieve that object then the 'adequacy' of the 'compensation' was not challengeable in a court. In Shantilal, the Court repudiated the idea of 'just equivalent'; it now laid emphasis merely on 'compensation' and would intervene only if it was 'illusory', or if the principles specified for the purpose were 'irrelevant'. To appreciate Shantilal ruling, it is necessary to remember that it is a well recognised principle of land acquisition that compensation is payable with reference to its value on the date of notification acquiring the land and not on the date the state takes actual possession thereof. The Court could not jettison this entrenched principle. So, it had to uphold the law in Shantilal even if it involved dilution of the Metal Corp. principle. The Shantilal case thus restored much greater freedom to the legislature to order compensation in the way it wanted for any property acquired. The scope of judicial review was restricted to the extreme situation of abuse of legislative power.27 Then came the celebrated Bank Nationalization case.28 It arose out of the nationalization of 11 commercial banks in 1969. The principles laid down in the relevant law for payment of compensation to the banks for their undertakings acquired was challenged on the ground that it did not seek to provide just compensation. This line of attack followed substantially the judicial approach adopted in Vajravelu and Metal Corporation. The government argued on the basis of Shantilal that it was not predicated for the validity of a law that it must aim at awarding just equivalent for the property acquired, and if the law was not confiscatory, or the principles to determine compensation not irrelevant, then the Court could not go into the propriety of such principles, or the adequacy or reasonableness of compensation. The Court ruled that if the principles specified by the law were relevant to the determination of compensation, then they would be beyond challenge. The Court explained that the principles adopted should be such as were appropriate to, and recognised for, determining the value of the class of property sought to be acquired. A method appropriate to determining the value of one class of property might be wholly inappropriate to determining the value of another class of property. There might be several appropriate principles to determine the value Page 86 of the class of property acquired. If one appropriate principle was applied to determine compensation, the fact that by applying another appropriate principle, a different value was reached was irrelevant. The method specified to value lands and buildings were not relevant to the determination of compensation. It emphasized that the entire undertaking should be taken as a unit for purposes of assessing compensation.
