F. EMERGENCY AND FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS Emergency has a debilitating effect on the rights of the people in a democratic country. For example, in the Page 159 U.S.A., which has constitutionally guaranteed Fundamental Rights comparable to those in India, the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus can be suspended when in case of rebellion or invasion, public interest requires it.54 The courts can, however, determine whether conditions have arisen to justify the suspension of habeas corpus. No other Fundamental Right can be suspended in the U.S.A., but during an emergency, courts do give somewhat restrictive interpretation to these rights than they do during the normal days.55 In Britain, during the two world wars, drastic discretionary powers were conferred on the Executive to interfere with the rights of property and person of the people. This drastic interference with people's rights received judicial sanction in several cases. The theory is that when the country is engaged in a war of survival, the people have to sacrifice their rights to some extent so that the state may live. If the state goes down, the people also go down.56 In India, a proclamation of emergency under Art. 352 affects the Fundamental Rights of the people very drastically.57 The impact of emergency on the Fundamental Rights is much more pervasive in India than is the case in the U.S.A. This topic may be discussed here under the following several heads. SUSPENSION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS (i) POSITION BEFORE 1978 (a) SUSPENSION OF ART. 19 According to Art. 358, as it existed prior to the year 1978, as soon as a proclamation of emergency was made under Art. 352, Art. 19 was suspended.58 Art. 358 stated that while a proclamation of emergency "is in operation, nothing in Art. 19 shall restrict the power of the State....to make any law or to take any executive action...." Under Art. 358, there was an automatic suspension of Art. 19, as soon as an emergency was declared under Art. 352. Suspension of Art. 19 during the pendency of the proclamation of emergency under Art. 352, removed the fetters on the legislative and executive powers imposed by Art. 19. If the Legislature made a law or the executive committed acts which were inconsistent with the Fundamental Rights guaranteed by Art. 19, their validity was not open to challenge either during the continuance of the emergency, or even thereafter. As soon as the proclamation ceased to operate, the legislative enactments passed, and the executive actions taken, during the course of the said emergency became inoperative to the extent to which they conflicted with the rights guaranteed under Art. 19 because as soon as the emergency was lifted, Art. 19 which was suspended during the emergency was automatically revived and began to operate. Article 358 made it clear that things done or omitted to be done during the emergency could not be challenged even after the emergency was over. In other words, the suspension of Art. 19 was complete during the period in question and legislative and executive action which contravened Art. 19 could not be questioned even after the emergency was over.59 (b) SUSPENSION OF OTHER FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS Article 359 refers to the suspension of the operation of all Fundamental Rights other than Art. 19 during an emergency proclaimed under Art. 352. Under Art. 359, Fundamental Rights as such are not suspended; what is suspended is their enforcement. Under Art. 359, as it stood prior to 1978, the enforcement of all Fundamental Rights (other than Art. 19 which is the subject-matter of Art. 358), could be suspended during an emergency by an executive order. When a proclamation of emergency was in operation, the President could by an order declare that the right to move any Court for the enforcement of any Fundamental Right, and all proceedings pending in any Court for the enforcement of that right, "shall remain suspended for the period during which the proclamation is in force or for such shorter period as may be specified in the order." (c) PREVENTIVE DETENTION AND EMERGENCY BEFORE 1975 A critical question which emerged during the emergencies of 1962 and 1971 was with respect to the scope of judicial review of preventive detention. When emergency was declared in 1962, enforcement of Arts. 14, 21 and 22 was suspended by the Presidential Order (PO) issued under Art. 359 as regards a person who was deprived of these rights under the Defence of India Act, or any rule or order made thereunder. Parliament then enacted the Defence of India Act, 1962, with a view to arm the Central Governmentwith extraordinary powers to deal with the emergency situation. S.3 of the Act authorised the government to make rules for securing the defence of India, civil defence, public safety, maintenance of public order and related matters.

30(i)(b) of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, made under the Act, authorised the Central or State Government to detain a person if it was satisfied that it was necessary to do so with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the defence of India, civil defence, public safety, maintenance of public order, India's relations with foreign powers, maintenance of peaceful conditions in any part of India, efficient conduct of military operations, or maintenance of supplies and services essential to the life of the community. Rule 30A set up a machinery for confirming and reviewing detention orders. The order of detention passed by an authorised officer was to be reviewed by a reviewing authority of two officials, and the order was then to be confirmed or cancelled by the government concerned. Further, each case of detention was to be reviewed regularly at a six monthly interval and the order of detention confirmed or cancelled by the government concerned. Rule 30(i)(b) thus made more drastic provisions regarding preventive detention than the Preventive Detention Act, as the rule made no provision for communicating grounds of detention to the detainee, or for making any representation by him at any stage; the rule fixed no maximum period of detention and review by the advisory board was done away with and, in its place, review by an official body was substituted. A similar situation developed when emergency was declared in 1971. In Makhan Singh v. State of Punjab, 78 a case which arose under the proclamation of emergency issued in 1962, the Supreme Court was called upon to consider the question whether any judicial review of detention under Rule 30(i)(b) was at all possible. A detainee challenged his detention as illegal and improper before the Punjab High Court under S. 491(b) of the Criminal Procedure Code. This section providedinter alia that "any High Court may whenever it thinks fit direct that a person illegally, or improperly detained in public custody be set at liberty." After the inauguration of the Constitution, S. 491 fell into deseutude because more efficacious remedies by way of Arts. 32 and 226 had come into vogue. S. 491 was now sought to be resurrected in Makhan Singh because enforcement of Art. 21 under Art. 32 was suspended. The main arguments of the petitioner were-- Page 163 (a) Although enforcement of Arts. 21 and 22 was suspended, these rights still subsisted and Rule 30(i)(b) was bad as it infringed these Articles; (b) What Art. 359 barred was enforcement of Arts. 21 and 22 through constitutional remedies under Arts. 32 and 226, but not under S. 491 , Cr.P.C. Rejecting these contentions, the Supreme Courtruled by majority that no action could lie under S. 491 , Cr.P.C., to enforce Arts. 21 and 22. Art. 359 barred the right to move 'any Court' to enforce these Fundamental Rights, and the words 'any Court' included theSupreme Courtas well as the High Courts, and, therefore, none of these courts could be moved for the purpose either under Arts. 32 or 226 or under S. 491 , Cr.P.C. No action to enforce Arts. 21 and 22 could now lie. TheSupreme Court, however, emphasized that judicial review on grounds other than the Fundamental Rights included in the PO was not barred, as Art. 359 only authorised suspension of the Fundamental Rights specified in the PO. A detenu could thus challenge his detention on such grounds as violation of the mandatory provisions of the detention law, or where the detention had been ordered mala fide, etc., as such pleas fell outside the purview of Art. 359 and, consequently, of the PO issued under Art. 359. Also, if a detenu contended that provisions of the Defence of India Act under which he was detained suffered from the vice of excessive delegation,79 such a plea could not be rejected at the threshold because it was not relatable to any Fundamental Right suspended by the PO. Also, a detenu could challenge an order of detention if it was made by an officer outside the authority conferred on him by the government. Defence of India Rule 30(i)(b) was of a very drastic nature and the courts were conscious of the possibility that uncontrolled administrative powers could be misused or abused. Although a detainee could not now challenge his detention on the basis of infringement of Art. 14, 21 or 22, yet, in subsequent cases, the Supreme Courtpermitted petitions to be filed under Rule 30(i)(b) on the ground that since the PO had suspended the enforcement of Arts. 14, 21 and 22 only in the context of the Defence of India Act, or rules or order made thereunder, a detention order not made in accordance with the Defence of India Rule in question was not under it and, thus, the PO did not bar remedy under Art. 32 to challenge the same. The PO could not bar a plea of the detention order being mala fide because such a plea was not relatable to the Fundamental Rights specified in the said PO. Similarly, a challenge to the Defence of India Act on the ground of excessive delegation could not be barred. Accordingly, the Supreme Courtentertained a writ petition under Art. 32 to challenge the Defence of India Act on the ground of excessive delegation, or to challenge Rule 30(i)(b) on the ground that it exceeded the rule-making power conferred by the Act, but the plea was rejected.80 The Supreme Courtalso ruled that the PO was conditional as its operation was limited to the Defence of India Act, or the Rules made thereunder. When a person was deprived of his personal liberty in contravention of the Defence of India Act, or the Rules, his right to move the Supreme Court or the High Court was not suspended.

The case in point is State of Maharashtra v. Prabhakar .81 The petitioner who was detained under Rule 30(1) of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, wrote a scientific book, but the State Government denied him permission to send the manuscript for publication. When the matter came before the Supreme Court, it ruled that the State Government had acted contrary to the law in refusing permission for publication of the manuscript. The Court explained that the PO suspended Art. 21 during the emergency period only to the extent that a person was deprived of his personal liberty under the Defence of India Act or the Rules. If the authority concerned imposed a restriction in violation of the law under which he was detained, he would be entitled to move the High Court or the Supreme Court. The result of the above judicial approach was that preventive detention under Rule 30(i)(b) became challengeable on all those grounds on which a discretionary decision can be challenged on the basis of the principles of Administrative Law.82 In this way, the courts succeeded in imposing a limited judicial review on the vast emergency administrative power to order preventive detention during an emergency. Thus, while the courts did maintain that the question of detaining a person was one of subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority, and hence not justiciable,83 an order of preventive detention could be quashed on such grounds as non-conformity with law,84mala fides,85 non-application of mind by the detaining authority to the materials Page 164 placed before it,86 taking into account irrelevant considerations by the detaining authority in issuing a detention order,87 or the detention order being based on illusory grounds,88 or lack of competence in the detaining authority to make a detention order because of some defect in his authority to do so.89 The Courts repeatedly emphasized that in a situation where a person could be deprived of his liberty simply by the issue of an administrative order, strict compliance with the letter of the law was necessary, and any deviation from the law in question would vitiate the order. A few examples of the judicial process in the area may be noted below: (i) Rule 30(i)(b) authorised preventive detention for 'maintenance of public order'. Therefore, detention for 'maintenance of law and order' fell outside the scope of the Rule and so was invalid because the concept of 'law and order' was broader than that of 'public order'.90 (ii) A detention order mentioned verbatim six out of the seven grounds mentioned in Rule 30(i)(b). When it was challenged, the Minister asserted in an affidavit that he was personally satisfied that the detention was necessary in order to prevent the detenu from acting against the safety of India and maintenance of public order. The affidavit made no reference to the four other grounds mentioned in the detention order. The Supreme Court quashed the detention order holding that the detaining authority had not applied its mind properly before passing the order. The Court emphasized that the authority had to be satisfied with respect to each of the grounds mentioned in the order.91 Rule 30A envisaged a six monthly review of a detention order.92 The Supreme Court laid down the following few propositions concerning this rule: (1) An order confirming detention after such review should be recorded in writing. If that was not done, there was failure to comply with the rule and the detention became invalid.93 (2) If a review was done after more than six months, Rule 30A was infringed and, therefore, the detention became invalid.94 (3) While the original order detaining a person under Rule 30(i)(b) was administrative in nature, the review under Rule 30A was a quasi-judicial proceeding.95 The practical implications of this ruling were that while under the rule, a detainee had no right to get the grounds of his detention and make representation against it, he got such a right under Rule 30A at the time of the review. Through these various rulings, the Supreme Court made a significant contribution towards mitigating somewhat the rigours of the emergency preventive detention. The Court sought to draw a balance between the interests of the country and individual liberty during an emergency. The Maintenance of Internal Security Act (MISA)2, was amended by Parliament to put into effect a more drastic version of preventive detention. The highlights of these amendments were as follows: (a) The Central or State Government, or the authorised officer could make a declaration, along with the order of preventive detention issued under MISA, that the detention of that specified individual was "necessary for dealing effectively with the emergency"; (b) Such a declaration meant that the certain safeguards which were available ordinarily under MISA to a detainee were not to be available to the specified individual. Thus, (i) the grounds of Page 165 his detention were not to be communicated to him; (ii) his case was not to be reviewed by the advisory board as envisaged in Art.

This meant that-- (i) The declaration made by the authorised official as to the 'necessity of detention' of an individual, was to be reviewed by the concerned government within 15 days; (ii) If the government failed to confirm the said declaration within this period, it was to cease to be effective; (iii) The detention of such a person was to be reconsidered by the appropriate government every four months; (iv) If it appeared to the government concerned that the detention of the person concerned was not necessary for 'effectively dealing' with the emergency, the declaration could be revoked in which case the normal safeguards of MISA could operate; (v) The State Government was to report the making of the detention order to the Central Government; and (vi) The Central Government could require the State Government to furnish to it the grounds on which the order was made and other particulars having a bearing on the necessity of the order. The government was thus vested with extraordinary power to detain persons without trial. The provisions of the amended MISA covering emergency detention were extremely drastic. India had never before witnessed such a rigorous version of preventive detention. A stone-wall was sought to be created around the grounds of detention. Only the Administration was to have knowledge of the grounds, and none else, not even the detainee. The provisions were so drafted as to exclude judicial review of any case of emergency detention. The only safeguard was the self-discipline of the government or the officers having the power to detain people, the review by the government of the exercise of the power by its officers, and four monthly review by the government of each case of detention, and, ultimately, control by the Central Government. The most crucial question which was raised in this connection was regarding the scope of judicial review of a detention order issued under the above provisions of MISA. A number of writ petitions were moved in various High Courts under Art. 226 challenging preventive detention orders as being not in compliance with law. It is at the basis of the Indian jurisprudence that if the executive derives powers under a statute, then it is subject to the doctrine of ultra vires. This principle has been applied in all kinds of situations to protect various kinds of rights whether fundamental or otherwise.10This is the foundational norm of the constitutional system in India. This norm is not derivable from any Fundamental Right. Art. 359 has been amended by the 44th Amendment of the Constitution.22 (ii) POSITION AFTER 1978 As a result of the Shukla ruling, the emergency provisions in the Indian Constitution came to be recast through the 44th Amendment of the Constitution enacted in 1978. Amendment 44 restricted the scope of Art. 358 in several ways. First, according to Art. 358(1), while a proclamation of emergency declaring that the security of India or any part thereof is threatened by war or by external aggression is in operation, nothing in Art. 19 shall restrict the power of the 'state' to make any law, or to take any executive action which the 'state' would, but for the provisions of Art. 19, be competent to make or to take. Article 19 is not suspended in case the proclamation of emergency has been issued on the ground of armed rebellion. Under Art. 358(1), there is an automatic suspension of Art. 19 as soon as emergency is proclaimed on the ground of war or external aggression, and Art. 19 ceases to restrain the legislature or the executive power of the State or the Centre. This means that the suspension of Art. 19 during the pendency of the proclamation of emergency removes the fetters imposed on the legislative and executive powers by Art. 19 and if the legislature makes a law, or the executive commits acts, which are inconsistent with the rights guaranteed by Art. 19, their validity is not open to challenge either during the continuance of the emergency Page 170 or even thereafter. Second, according to Cl. 2 of Art. 358, Art. 358(1) does not apply to: (i) any law which does not contain a recital to the effect that such law is in relation to the proclamation of emergency in operation when it is made; or, (ii) any executive action taken otherwise than under a law containing such a recital. Article 358(2) makes it clear that only a law enacted in relation to the emergency, but no other law, would be immune from being challenged under Art. 358 during an emergency. In (ii) mentioned above, "action under a law" suggests that any action which is ultra vires the law is not protected. According to a proviso to Art. 358(1), where the proclamation of emergency is in operation only in a part of India, any such law may be made, or executive action taken, in relation to the area where the proclamation is not in operation if the security of India is threatened by activities in or in relation to that part in which the proclamation is in operation. This provision makes it possible to extend any law or executive action taken in the part in which emergency prevails to any other part of the country if activities therein threaten the security of India or any part thereof. The effect of Art. 358 thus is that a law of the type mentioned above enacted during the emergency cannot be challenged under Art. 19.23 As soon as the proclamation of emergency is issued on the ground of war or external aggression, Art. 19 ceases to restrict the power of Parliament to make laws. This is an automatic incidence of a proclamation of emergency on the ground of war or external aggression. The power of Parliament thus becomes wider. Similarly the executive power becomes free from the shackles of Art. 19. Any law containing the necessary recital, i.e., 'the law relates to the emergency', is unchallengeable in a Court under Art. 19. The same immunity extends mutatis mutandis to an ordinance made by the President or the Governor for an ordinance has the same effect as an Act.24 The proposition is well-established that Art. 19 becomes ineffective only vis-a-vis a law enacted during the emergency but not with respect to a pre-emergency law. Thus, while the validity of a law enacted during the emergency cannot be challenged on the ground that it infringes Art. 19, the pre-emergency laws can still be challenged on that ground. If such a law was invalid when enacted because it infringed Art. 19 at that time, it remains invalid and would not be revived even when emergency is declared and Art. 19 is suspended. Article 358 is prospective; it does not operate to validate a legislative provision which was invalid because of a constitutional inhibition before the proclamation of emergency. The doctrine of eclipse cannot apply in such a case as such a law would be regarded as voidab initio.25 The plenary power of law-making expanded in pursuance of Art. 358 only from the date of the Proclamation of Emergency and not earlier. An executive action of the type mentioned above taken during emergency cannot also be challenged on the ground that it infringes Art. 19. But such an executive action must otherwise be competent. If it is ultra vires the law under which it is being taken, it is not protected by Art. 358.26 An executive action which is otherwise invalid (outside Art. 19), is not immune from attack, merely because a proclamation of emergency is in operation when it is taken. During the emergency, Art. 19 is suspended, but that cannot authorise the taking of detrimental executive action without any legislative authority, or even in purported exercise of power conferred by any pre-emergency law which was invalid when enacted. In several cases, immunity under Art. 358 has been refused to such executive action as has emanated from, or is a continuation of, the pre-emergency legislation or executive action. Thus, in Bennett Coleman,27 the newsprint policy for 1972-73 of the Central Governmentwas challenged under Art. 19(1)(a). The policy was an emanation from the Newsprint Control Order, 1962, which was made under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955, and the Imports and Exports Act of 1947, both being pre-emergency laws. TheSupreme Court Page 171 ruled that the impugned policy being a continuation of the old policy, was not immunized by Art. 358. In the words of the Court, " Art.

Court Page 171 ruled that the impugned policy being a continuation of the old policy, was not immunized by Art. 358. In the words of the Court, " Art. 358 does not apply to executive action taken during the emergency if the same is a continuation of the prior executive action or an emanation of the previous law which prior executive action or previous law would otherwise be violative of Art. 19 or be otherwise unconstitutional." Later judicial pronouncements have extended the proposition to executive action taken during an emergency under a valid pre-emergency law. Thus, in Shree Meenakshi Mills,28 the Supreme Court ruled that the validity of the notifications issued in 1973 (during emergency) under a pre-emergency law, viz., the Cotton Textiles (Control) Order, 1948, could be challenged under Arts. 19(1)(f) and (g).29 Similar is the ruling of the Punjab High Court which emphasized that Art. 358 immunized new legislation enacted during emergency from an attack under Art. 19, but the state would not thereby become entitled, during emergency to exercise arbitrary powers under pre-emergency legislation. Therefore, delegated legislation made during the emergency under a pre-emergency law can still be challenged under Art. 19.30 The courts have thus given somewhat restrictive operation to Art. 358 as regards pre-emergency legislation and executive action taken during emergency under pre-emergency legislation. As soon as the proclamation of emergency comes to an end, Art. 19 automatically comes back to life and begins to operate. Any statutory provisions passed, and the executive action taken during the emergency can be challenged under Art. 19. Any law inconsistent with Art. 19, made during the emergency, ceases to operate to the extent of its inconsistency with Art. 19. But the liability incurred for acts or omissions during the emergency cannot be nullified even if it be assumed that the Act in question was violative of Art. 19. Article 358, however, makes it clear that things done or omitted to be done during the emergency cannot be challenged even after the emergency is over. In other words, the suspension of Art. 19 is complete during the period in question and legislative and executive action which contravene Art. 19 cannot be questioned even after the emergency is over.31 The result of this clause is that no Act of Indemnity is necessary to immunize against liability for acts done during emergency provided these acts were done under a law containing a recital saying that the law is in relation to the Proclamation of Emergency. Thus, the liability created by an act or omission when the Acts were in operation during the currency of the proclamation of emergency cannot be challenged even after the revocation of the proclamation on the ground that the provisions of the Acts violated Art. 19. The Supreme Court has now explained the effect of Art. 358 as follows in Attorney General for India v. Amratlal Prajivandas.32 Art. 358(1) enables the state to make any law or to take any executive action inconsistent with Art. 19. This power is confined to the period of emergency. As soon as the emergency ceases, the law so made shall, to the extent of inconsistency with Art. 19, cease to have effect, except with respect to things done or omitted to be done before the law so ceases to have effect. "What it means is that the validity of the law made or the things done or omitted to be done by virtue of the said Article during the period of emergency cannot be questioned either during or after the emergency on the ground of inconsistency with Art. 19." Thus, if the freedom of speech has been curtailed during the emergency to the extent not warranted by Art. 19(2), the citizen whose right has been unreasonably curtailed cannot sue the state for damages or any other relief nor can he take any other proceeding for unreasonably curtailing his right during the emergency period. SUSPENSION OF OTHER FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS Article 359 refers to the suspension of the operation of all Fundamental Rights other than Art. 19 during an emergency. Under Art. 359, Fundamental Rights as such are not suspended, but only their enforcement. Before the 44th Amendment, the enforcement of all Fundamental Rights (other than Art. 19 which is the subject-matter of Art. 358), could be suspended during an emergency through a Presidential Order. But to curtail the vast power vested in the executive, the 44th Amendment restricts the scope of Art. 359 somewhat. Art. 359 has been amended so as to provide that the presidential power to suspend the right to move the Court for the enforcement of a Fundamental Right cannot be exercised in respect of the Page 172 Fundamental Rights guaranteed by Arts. 20 and 21. Thus, it is no longer possible to suspend the right to life and personal liberty guaranteed by Art. 21, and the right to protection in respect of conviction for offences guaranteed by Art. 20. The 44th Amendment will obviate in future the situation depicted by the Shukla case. Making Art. 20 inviolate during an emergency means that the government could not harass the people during an emergency by making acts punishable retroactively. The Constitution Amendment 44 also provides further that the suspension of the enforcement of any Fundamental Right under Art. 359 shall not apply in relation to any law which does not contain a recital to the effect that such law is in relation to the proclamation of emergency in operation when it is made, or to any executive action taken otherwise than under a law containing such a recital. Thus, laws other than those passed for the purposes of the emergency will no longer be protected by the Presidential Order issued under Art. 359. Under Art. 359(1), when a proclamation of emergency is in operation, the President may by Order declare that the right to move any Court for the enforcement of such of the Fundamental Rights as may be mentioned in the Order (except Arts.

Under Art. 359(1), when a proclamation of emergency is in operation, the President may by Order declare that the right to move any Court for the enforcement of such of the Fundamental Rights as may be mentioned in the Order (except Arts. 20 and 21),33 and all proceedings pending in any Court for the enforcement of the rights so mentioned, shall remain suspended for the period during which the proclamation is in force, or for such shorter period as may be specified in the Order. What the Presidential Order purports to do under Art. 359(1) is to bar the remedy of the citizens to move any Court for the enforcement of the specified rights. The rights are not expressly suspended, but the citizen is deprived of his right to move any Court for their enforcement. The words of Art. 359(1) are clear and unambiguous. They only speak of suspending the enforcement of the rights but not suspending the rights themselves. The PO issued under Art. 359 does not suspend the rights mentioned therein; what is suspended is their operation. According to Art. 359(1-A), while an Order under Art. 359(1) is in operation, no Fundamental Right mentioned in the said Order (except 20 and 21) "shall restrict the power of the state to make any law or to take any executive action" which the state would be competent to make or take but for the Fundamental Rights in question "but any law so made shall, to the extent of inconsistency, cease to have effect as soon as the order aforesaid ceases to operate except as respects things done or omitted to be done before the law so ceases to have effect". These words have been borrowed from Art. 358(1) and added to Art. 359 as well. The result is that during the period the Presidential Order suspending enforcement of certain Fundamental Rights is in operation, the state is empowered to make any law or take any executive action inconsistent with such rights. This is so even though in theory these rights are not suspended; they remain alive and only their enforcement is suspended, but Art. 359(1A) has to be given effect to. According to Art. 359(1-B), Art. 359(1-A) does not apply to any law which does not contain a recital to the effect that such law is in relation to the proclamation of emergency in operation when it is made, or to any executive action taken otherwise than under a law containing such a recital. Thus, as regards laws other than those needed for the emergency, all Fundamental Rights continue to operate. According to Art. 359(3), any order made under Art. 359(1) shall, as soon as may be after it is made, be laid before each House of Parliament. According to Art. 359(2), any Presidential Order made under Art. 359(1) may extend to the whole or any part of the territory of India. According to a proviso to Art. 359(2), where a proclamation of emergency is in operation only in part of the Indian territory, any such Order shall not extend to any other part of the territory of India unless the President, being satisfied that the security of India or any part thereof is threatened by activities in or in relation to the part of the territory of India in which the proclamation is in operation, considers such extension to be necessary. There are several points of distinction between Arts. 358 and 359. (i) While Art. 19 is suspended automatically under Art. 358 as soon as the emergency is Page 173 proclaimed, under Art. 359, enforcement of other Fundamental Rights is not so suspended. (ii) In case of Fundamental Rights other than Art. 19, what can be suspended under Art. 359 is their enforcement and that, too, not automatically, but only by an Order of the President and to the extent the President decrees in his Order. (iii) Further, while under Art. 358, Art. 19 remains suspended for the whole of the duration of the emergency, under Art. 359, enforcement of other Fundamental Rights remains suspended so long as the President ordains which may either be the entire duration of the emergency, or a shorter period. (iv) Also, while suspension of Art. 19 is for the entire country and so covers all legislatures and all States, the Order under Art. 359 may extend to the whole or a part of India. (v) Art. 359 operates in any emergency proclaimed under Art. 352, but Art. 358 operates only in case of an emergency on the ground of threat to the security of the country because of war or external aggression. (vi) Under Art. 359, enforcement of Arts. 20 and 21 cannot be suspended. It thus appears that prima facie the effect of Art. 359 is less drastic on the Fundamental Rights than the effect of Art. 358 on Art. 19. The position now is that while enforcement of Art. 21 is not to be suspended at all during an emergency, Art. 22 can be suspended. Thus, the safeguards contained in Art. 22 can be nullified as regards preventive detention. The effect of this will be as follows: (i) A law is necessary to put a person in detention because Art. 21 requires that a person cannot be deprived of his personal liberty without procedure established by law.34 (ii) An order of preventive detention can be challenged not on the ground of any violation of a safeguard contained in Art. 22, but on such grounds as mala fides, or detention not being in accordance with the relevant law, or on any ground on which the exercise of any discretionary power can be challenged under Administrative Law for in such a case the order will cease to be in accordance with law; (iii) The Courts can import principles of natural justice or fairness or reasonableness into such a law as has been held in the Maneka Gandhi case.35 Although, the safeguards under Art.

may not be available to a detenu, as such, the Courts may, nevertheless, insist on some safeguards for the detenu on the ground that Art. 21 envisages not any procedure, but a fair, just and reasonable procedure; (iv) As enforcement of Art. 20 cannot also be suspended now during an emergency, the safeguards available thereunder to a person accused of a criminal offence cannot be suspended. As has already been pointed out, the Forty-fourth Constitution Amendment made a number of changes in the Emergency Provisions of the Constitution so as to avoid any misuse of power in future in the name of emergency. Arts. 358 and 359 were also amended. Art. 359 has been amended so as to ensure that never in future in case of declaration of emergency in the country under Art. 352, the Fundamental Rights guaranteed by Arts. 20 and 21 would be suspended. In Amratlal Prajivandas,36 an interesting question was raised. Under the Smugglers and Foreign Exchange Manipulators (Forfeiture of Property) Act, 1976 [SAFEMA], the property of a person who was detained under COFEPOSA was to be forfeited. The argument in the instant case was that during the Emergency, COFEPOSA was made much more drastic so as to be inconsistent with Art. 22. So an order of preventive detention was ultra vires Art. 22. Such an order could be tolerated during the emergency but it should be treated for other purposes as void and non-est as Art. 22 was not suspended, only its enforcement was suspended under Art. 359(1). Such an order of detention should not be regarded as an order for the purposes of SAFEMA. So the question was whether it can be said that a detention order made inconsistent with Art. 22 (which was suspended), was void or non-est even though it could not be challenged during the emergency period. In reply the Supreme Court has ruled that such an order of preventive detention could not be treated as void Page 174 or non-existent for the purposes of SAFEMA. Such an order of detention made under COFEPOSA, "is an order of detention within the meaning and purposes of S. 2(2)(b) of SAFEMA." G. NATIONAL HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION NHRC has been set up as a statutory body under the Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993. The purpose of setting up the Commission is to strengthen the machinery for more effective enforcement of Fundamental Rights of the people. The Statement of Objects and Reasons appended to the Bill which later became the Act made clear the purposes underlying the proposed enactment. While noting that India was a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, both of which were adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on 16th December 1966, and that the rights embodied in those Covenants stood substantially protected by the Constitution of India, the Statement observed that there had been "growing concern in the country and abroad about issues relating to human rights." Having regard to this, and to the changing social realities and emerging trends in the nature of crime and violence, it has been considered essential to review the existing laws and procedures and the system of administration with a view to bringing about greater efficiency and transparency. The Act provides for the establishment of the National Human Rights Commission, the State Human Rights Commissions in the States, and the Human Rights Courts for the better protection of human rights and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto. The Central Government constitutes the NHRC. The Commission consists of the following: (1) A chairperson who has been the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of India; (2) One member who is or has been a Judge of the Supreme Court; (3) One member who is or has been the Chief Justice of a High Court; and (4) Two members who are to be appointed from amongst the persons having knowledge of, or practical experience in, matters relating to human rights. The chairperson and members of the Commission are to be appointed by the President of India. Every such appointment is to be made after securing the recommendations of a committee consisting of the following persons: (i) Prime Minister as chairperson; (ii) Speaker of the Lok Sabha; (iii) Minister in charge of the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India; (iv) Leader of the Opposition in the Lok Sabha; (v) Leader of the Opposition in the Rajya Sabha; and (vi) Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha. The Chairperson of the Commission holds office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office, or until he attains the age of 70 years, whichever is earlier. A member holds office for a term of five years and he is eligible for appointment for one more term of five years. However, no member shall hold office after he reaches the age of 70 years. After ceasing to hold office, the Chairperson or a member is not eligible for any appointment under the Government of India or of a State Government. Salaries and allowances payable to the members shall be as prescribed. The salary and allowances of a member shall not be varied to his disadvantage after he has been appointed. To make members of the Commission independent of government control, the Act provides that the Chairperson or any member of the Commission shall not be removable except by an order of the President on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity after the Supreme Court, on a reference being made to it by the President, has, after an inquiry held in accordance with the procedure prescribed by the Supreme Page 175 Court, reported that the chairperson or the member concerned, as the case may be, ought on such ground be removed.

President may, however, remove the chairperson or a member from office if he: (i) is adjudged insolvent; or (ii) engages during his term of office in any paid employment outside the duties of his office; or (iii) is unfit to continue in office because of infirmity of mind or body, or (iv) is of unsound mind and is so declared by a competent Court; or (v) is convicted and sentenced to imprisonment for an offence which in the opinion of the President involves moral turpitude. The Chairpersons of the National Commission for Minorities,37 the National Commission for Women38 and the National Commission for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes39 are deemed to be members of the Commission for (NHRC) the discharge of the various functions assigned to it, except for the function relating to inquiry into complaints of violation of human rights, viz., the function mentioned in S. 12(a)(i) and (ii) of the Act. Individuals and interested parties can make complaints to the Commission regarding violations of human rights in the country. A number of complaints received by the Commission are dismissed on one of the following grounds: (1) The complaint does not fall within the purview of the Commission; (2) The matter is sub judice or pending before another Commission; (3) The event which is the object of the Complaint, occurred more than one year before the making of the complaint; (4) The complaint is vague or frivolous and no specific case has been made out of a human rights violation. Sections 11(1) and (2) of the Act provide that: (1) The Central Government shall make available to the Commission:-- (a) an officer of the rank of Secretary to the Government of India who shall be the Secretary General of the Commission; and (b) such police and investigative staff under an officer not below the rank of a Director General of Police and such other officers and staff as may be necessary for the efficient performance of the functions of the Commission. (2) Subject to such rules as may be made by the Central Government in this behalf, the Commission may appoint such other administrative, technical and scientific staff as it may consider necessary. The functions to be discharged by the Commission are listed in S. 12 of the Act. These are: (a) to inquire, suo motu or on a petition presented to it by a victim or any person on his behalf, into complaint of-- (i) violation of human rights or abetment thereof, or (ii) negligence in the prevention of such violation, by a public servant; (b) to intervene in any proceeding involving any allegation of violation of human rights pending before a Court with the approval of such Court; (c) to visit, under intimation to the State Government, any jail or any other institution under the control of the State Government, where persons are detained or lodged for purposes of treatment, reformation or protection to study the living conditions of the inmates and make recommendations thereon; (d) to review the safeguards provided by or under the Constitution or any law for the time being in force for the protection of human rights and recommend measures for their effective implementation; (e) to review the factors, including acts of terrorism that inhibit the employment of human rights and Page 176 recommend appropriate remedial measures; (f) to study treaties and other international instruments on human rights and make recommendations for their effective implementation; (g) to undertake and promote research in the field of human rights; (h) to spread human rights literacy among various sections of society and promote awareness of the safeguards available for the protection of these rights through publications, the media, seminars, and other available means; (i) to encourage the efforts of non-governmental organisations and institutions working in the field of human rights; (j) such other functions as it may consider necessary for the promotion of human rights. In S. 12(a), the expression human rights has been used. S. 2(b) of the Act defines 'human rights' to mean "the rights relating to life, liberty, equality and dignity of the individual guaranteed by the Constitution, embodied in the International Conventions and enforceable by courts in India." Thus, the rights guaranteed by International Conventions to which India has acceded have been included within the term "human rights". Commenting on the above definition, the Supreme Court has observed in Madhu Kishwar v. State of Bihar :40 "Thereby the principles embodied in CEDAW and the concomitant Right to Development become integral parts of the Indian Constitution and the Human Rights Act and became enforceable. S. 12of the Protection of Human Rights Act charges the Commission with duty for proper implementation as well as prevention of violation of the human rights and fundamental freedoms." CEDAW, mentioned above, stands for the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. This Convention was adopted by the UN General Assembly on December 18, 1979, and the Government of India ratified the Convention on June 19, 1993, and acceded to CEDAW on August 8, 1993. The Government however made some reservations on Articles 5(e), 16(1), 16(2) and 29 of the Convention which condemns discrimination against women in all its forms. The Commission has been given ample powers to enable it to discharge its functions effectively. The Commission has power to regulate its own procedure. It has, while inquiring into complaints under the Act, powers of a civil Court trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure, and, in particular, in respect of the following matters: (i) summoning and enforcing the attendance of witnesses and examining them on oath; (ii) discovery and production of documents; (iii) receiving evidence in affidavits; (iv) requisitioning any public record or copy thereof from any Court or office; (v) issuing commissions for the examination of witnesses or documents; (vi) any other manner which may be prescribed. Any officer or agency conducting any investigation on behalf of the Commission enjoys similar powers.

The Commission has power to require any person, subject to any privilege which may be claimed by that person, under any law for the time being in force, to furnish information on such points or matters as, in the opinion of the Commission, may be useful for, or relevant to, the subject matter of the inquiry. Any person so required is legally bound to furnish such information within the meaning of Ss. 176 and 177 of the Indian Penal Code. The Commission or any of its authorised officer may enter any building or place where the Commission has reason to believe that any document relating to the subject matter of the inquiry may be found, and may seize any such document. This power is subject to S. 100 , Cr.P.C. The Commission is deemed to be a civil Court. When any of the following offences is committed; viz;S. 175 , IPC,41 178, IPC,42S. 179IPC,43S. 180 , IPC,44S. 228 , IPC,45in the view or presence of the Commission, the Commission may, after recording the facts constituting the offence and the statement of the accused as provided for in the Cr.P.C., forward the case to a magistrate and he will proceed to hear the complaint Page 177 against the accused. Every proceeding before the Commission is to be regarded as a judicial proceeding within the meaning of Ss. 193 (punishment for false evidence) and 228, IPC, (intentional insult or interruption to public servant sitting in judicial capacity) and for the purposes of s. 196 , IPC. The Commission is regarded as a civil Court for all purposes of S. 195 , Cr.P.C., and Chapter XXVI, Cr.P.C.46 The Commission is authorised, for the purpose of conducting any investigation pertaining to the inquiry, to utilise the services of any officer or investigation agency of the Central or State Government with its permission. No statement made by a person in the course of giving evidence before the Commission shall subject him to, or be used against him, in any civil or criminal proceeding except a prosecution for giving false evidence, provided that that the statement--(a) is made in reply to the question which he is required by the Commission to answer; or (b) is relevant to the subject matter of the inquiry. If the Commission considers it necessary to inquire into the conduct of any person, or is of the opinion that the reputation of any person is likely to be prejudicially affected by the inquiry, the Commission must give that person a reasonable opportunity of being heard in the inquiry and to produce evidence in his defence. While inquiring into any complaint of violation of human rights, the Commission may call for information from the Central or the State Government or any other authority or organisation subordinate thereto within such time as may be specified by it. If the Commission does not receive information within the time stipulated, it may proceed to inquire into the matter by itself. If on receiving information, the Commission is satisfied that no further inquiry is required, or that the required action has been taken by the concerned government or authority, it may not proceed with the complaint and inform the complainant accordingly. The Commission is authorised to take any of the following steps on the completion of an inquiry: (i) where the inquiry disclosed violation of human rights, the Commission may recommend to the concerned government or authority the initiation of proceedings for prosecution or such other action against the concerned person or persons; (ii) approach the Supreme Court or the concerned High Court for such directions, orders or writs as that Court may deem necessary; (iii) recommend to the concerned authority the grant of an interim relief to the victim or the members of his family as the Commission may consider necessary; (iv) provide a copy of the inquiry report to the petitioner or his representative; (v) send a copy of the inquiry report together with its recommendations to the concerned government or authority and the concerned government or authority shall, within a period of one month or such further time as the Commission may allow, forward its comments on the report, including the action taken or proposed to be taken thereon, to the Commission; (vi) shall publish its inquiry report together with the comments of the concerned government or authority, if any, and the action taken or proposed to be taken by the concerned government or authority on the recommendation of the Commission. The Act lays down special procedure for dealing with complaints of violation of human rights by members of the armed forces. The Commission has to submit an annual report to the Central Government and to the State Government concerned. The Commission may submit special reports on any matter which, in its opinion, is of such urgency or importance that it should not be deferred till submission of the annual report [ S. 20(1)]. The Central Government or the State Government, as the case may be, shall cause the annual or the special report of the Commission to be laid before each House of Parliament or the State Legislature respectively, as the case may be, along with a memorandum of action taken or proposed to be taken of the recommendations of the Commission and the reasons for the non-acceptance of the recommendations, if any. The functions assigned to NHRC are vast in scope and range. The Commission is required not only to Page 178 promote and protect all the Fundamental Rights enshrined in the Constitution of India but also those covered by treaties to which India is a party.

Most of the complaints which come before the Commission relate to such matters as custodial deaths and rape, disappearance of persons from custody, cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment and torture, gender related violence, atrocities against vulnerable sectors of society, such as, women, children and the disabled, especially those belonging to the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. The Commission can take cognisance of a matter suo motu even if it receives no complaint about it. S. 12(d) of the PHRA, 1993, requires the Commission to "review the safeguards provided by or under the Constitution or any law for the time being in force for the protection of human rights and recommend measures, for their effective implementation. Accordingly, the Commission monitored the implementation of Tada [--a draconian Law and, finally, suggested that this law be repealed.47 Under S. 12(b), the Commission can intervene in Court proceedings pertaining to enforcement of human rights.48 S. 12(c) authorises the Commission to make recommendations on the prison conditions. The Commission has expressed its concern about the appalling conditions of over-crowding, lack of sanitation, poor medical facilities, etc. in most of the jails in the country.49 A very significant responsibility has been entrusted to the Commission under S. 12(b) which requires the Commission "to spread human rights literacy among various sections of society." The Commission has been taking steps to fulfil this responsibility.50 Section 12(g) entrusts the Commission with the responsibility of undertaking and promoting research in the field of human rights. Further S. 12(i) asks the Commission to encourage the efforts of non-government organizations working in the field of human rights. This is important for NGOs are life and soul of the effort to promote and protect human rights.51 The Commission has explicitly stated that women's rights will be a part of its concerns. The Supreme Court has given a much wider dimension to the functioning of the NHRC through its ruling in Paramjit Kaur v. State of Punjab .52 The Court has held that under Art. 32, it can refer any matter to the Commission for inquiry and the Commission then acts sui generis under the remit of the Supreme Court and, in such a case, the Commission is not bound by the shackles and limitations of the NHRC Act. The Court has described the Commission as "a unique expert body in itself". Fundamental Rights guaranteed by the Constitution represent the basic human rights possessed by every human being. The Supreme Court's jurisdiction under Art. 32 "cannot be curtailed by any statutory limitation" including those contained in the various provisions of NHRC Act. The Court has emphasized that all authorities in the country are bound by the directions of the Supreme Court and have to act in aid of the Court [ Art. 144].53 Therefore, when the Court in exercise of its jurisdiction under Art. 32 entrusts to the NHRC to deal with certain matter in the manner indicated in the Court order--the Commission would function pursuant to the directions issued by the Supreme Court and not under the Act constituting it. The Court has observed:54 "In deciding the matters referred by this Court, NHRC is given a free hand and is not circumscribed by any conditions. Therefore, the jurisdiction exercised by the Commission in these matters is of a special nature not covered by enactment or law and thus acts sui generis." Reference may be made to another Supreme Court pronouncement in NHRC v. Arunachal Pradesh .55 Here the Commission assumes a new role--that of a writ petitioner before the Supreme Court. A large number of Chakmas had crossed over from Bangladesh and were residing in Arunachal Pradesh for some time. The local students body resented this and threatened to evict the Chakmas by force. The Commission came to the conclusion that the local officers were siding with the students and there was imminent threat to the lives of the Chakmas. The Commission, therefore, decided to file a writ petition in the Supreme Court under Art. 32 seeking enforcement of the rights of Chakmas under Art. 21 of the Constitution.56 The Court allowed the Page 179 petition and directed the State to ensure the life and personal liberty of each Chakma and to ensure that they are not evicted from the State except in accordance with law. The Court pointed out that the country is governed by Rule of Law. The State is bound to protect the life and liberty of every human being, be he a citizen or otherwise. Accordingly, the Court directed the State, to repel by force any attempt to evict the Chakmas by force from the State. NHRC acts as a watchdog to protect human rights. It is expected to play an active role in ending violations of human rights. The most important feature of the Commission is its power to independently probe cases of violations of human rights. The Commission can act suo motu without waiting for any formal application if any violation of a human right comes to its notice. The term "human rights" has been broadly defined. The Commission is expected to play an active role in ending violations of human rights.57 STATE HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION The Act also makes provisions [ S. 21] for the State Governments to constitute similar commissions in the States. A State Commission is to consist of five members--one Chairperson who has been the Chief Justice of a High Court; one member who has been a Judge of the High Court; one member who has been a district judge and two other members to be appointed from amongst persons having knowledge and practical experience in matters relating to human rights.

Most of the provisions applicable to the National Commission also apply to the State Commission. A State Commission may inquire into violation of human rights only in respect of matters relatable to the entries enumerated in Lists II and III of the VII Schedule to the Constitution.58 The State Government may specify for each district a Court of session to be the Human Rights Court for speedy trial of offences arising out of violations of human rights. The State Government is to exercise this power with the concurrence of the Chief Justice of the High Court. For every such Human Rights Court, the State Government has to specify a public prosecutor or appoint an advocate, who has been in practice as an advocate for not less than seven years. There are many reasons to support the establishment of the State Human Rights Commissions. India is a big country and, therefore, there should be State Commissions as well in addition to the National Commission. The redressal of grievances of breach of human rights must be swift and inexpensive, the message of human rights must reach the grass root level. The federal character of the country should be respected by establishing separate National and State HRCs. Such Commissions have been established in several States. NATURE OF THE DIRECTIVE PRINCIPLES Articles 36 to 51 contain the Directive Principles of State Policy. The idea to have such principles in the Constitution has been borrowed from the Irish Constitution. There was a time, known as the laissez faire era, when the state was mainly concerned with the maintenance of law and order and defence of the country against external aggression. Such a restrictive concept of the state no longer remains valid. The makers of the Constitution had realized that in a poor country like India, political democracy would be useless without economic democracy. Accordingly, they incorporated a few provisions in the Constitution with a view to achieve amelioration of the socio-economic condition of the masses. Today we are living in an era of welfare state which seeks to promote the prosperity and well-being of the people. The Directive Principles strengthen and promote this concept by seeking to lay down some socio-economic goals which the various governments in India have to strive to achieve. The Directive Principles are designed to usher in a social and economic democracy in the country. These principles obligate the state to take positive action in certain directions in order to promote the welfare of the people and achieve economic democracy. These principles give directions to the legislatures and the executive in India as regards the manner in which they should exercise their power.1 In a number of pronouncements, the Supreme Court has insisted that these Directive Principles seek to introduce the concept of a welfare state in the country. Thus, we find the Supreme Court observing in Paschim Banga:2 "The Constitution envisages the establishment of a welfare state at the federal level as well as the State level. In a welfare state the primary duty of the Government is to secure the welfare of the people." The Directive Principles differ from Fundamental Rights3 which enjoin the state to refrain from taking prejudicial action against an individual and, thus, impose a negative duty on the state. Fundamental Rights seek to introduce an egalitarian society and to ensure liberty for all. The Directive Principles seek to achieve a welfare state. The two together constitute the conscience of the Constitution. Originally, the Directive Principles were more akin to moral, rather than to legal, precepts as they did not have much value from a legal point of view. The main idea underlying these principles was that they would serve an educational purpose, and might serve as restraints on those who come in power. These persons would have to pay some respect to those principles while exercising power, and could be held accountable for ignoring them before the electorate if not before a Court of law. In the Constituent Assembly, Dr. Ambedkar had said that a party which failed to implement these principles would stand to lose in the next elections. Thus, the accountability to enforce these principles was left to the political process.

The term 'state' in Art. 37 has the same meaning as has been given to it in Art. 12 and which has been explained earlier.4 Page 192 PREAMBLE TO THE CONSTITUTION The Preamble to the Constitution lays down the goals of politico-socio-economic democracy for the citizens of India.5 The Preamble emphasizes that India should be a socialist secular democratic republic. The Preamble further states that the People of India have given the Constitution to themselves to secure to all its citizens justice--social, economic and political; liberty of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship; Equality of status and of opportunity, and Fraternity assuring the dignity of the individual. The three concepts-liberty, equality and fraternity--constitute a trinity; one cannot be divorced from the other. The Supreme Court has emphasized in Keshavananda6 that the Preamble to the Constitution emphasizes the principle of equality as basic to the Indian Constitution. This is the basic feature of the Constitution which no legislature in India can transgress. Even an Amendment of the Constitution offending a basic structure of the Constitution is ultra vires. It may however be mentioned here that in India, the concept of equality is regarded not as a static, but a dynamic concept. It permits every process of equalisation and protective discrimination. Progressive measures to eliminate group disabilities and promote collective equality are not regarded as antagonistic to the concept of equality on the ground that every individual is entitled to equality of opportunity based purely on merit. Such an approach would perpetuate existing inequalities. Those who are unequal, in fact, cannot be treated by identical standards. That may amount to equality in law or formal equality but it would certainly not be real or substantive equality. It is necessary to take into account de facto inequalities which exist in society and to remove which affirmative action needs to be taken. This may involve giving preference to the socially and educationally disadvantaged persons, or inflicting handicaps on those more advantageously placed. Such affirmative action though apparently discriminatory is calculated to produce equality on a broader basis by eliminating de facto inequalities.7 As the Supreme Court has observed in Valsamma:8 "In other words, equal protection requires affirmative action for those unequals handicapped due to historical facts of untouchability practised for millennium which is abolished by Article 17; for Tribes living away from our national mainstream due to social and educational backwardness of OBCs".9 Further, the Constitution-makers rightly perceived that mere political democracy would be meaningless in a country of the poor millions without economic justice. The ideals stated in the Preamble are reinforced through the Directive Principles of State Policy which spell out in greater detail the goal of economic democracy, the socio-economic content of political freedom, the concept of a welfare state. The Directive Principles thus supplement the Preamble to the Constitution. These principles have been characterised as 'basic to our social order' as they seek to build a socially just society. These principles have been drafted in flexible and general language and leave enough leeway to the various governments in the country to frame their policies from time to time in accordance with the contemporary needs and circumstances of the society to achieve the goals set out therein. These principles do not impose any particular socio-economic philosophy on the country. These principles have played a crucial role in legislative and administrative policy-making in the country. They have inspired the idea of a socialist pattern of society; the process of planning has been oriented towards achieving the goals contained in them;10 agrarian economy has been restructured; right to property has been very much diluted;11 public industrial and economic sector has extended and a pervasive system of government regulation of private economic enterprise has been created12. Constant efforts are being made to improve the position of backward and economically weaker sections of society.13 However, in spite of the best intentions to fulfil these principles, there have been deficiencies in the implementation of the policies framed for the purpose and much remains to be done.14 While a surfeit of laws have been enacted to promote the programmes and policies envisaged by the Directive Principles, there has been failure on the part of the administration by way of non-administration, maladministration and misadministration of these laws. Recently the Supreme Court observed "the State Government is totally oblivious of its responsibilities regarding implementation of social welfare programmes of providing secured homes to destitute women and Page 193 also children in conflict with law".15 Originally, the word 'socialist' did not appear in the Preamble. In 1976, the Preamble was amended by the 42nd Constitution Amendment to give socialist orientation to the Indian Polity as India was now declared as a "Sovereign Socialist Secular Democracy". The term "socialist" has been brought in the Constitution to establish an egalitarian social order through rule of law as it basic structure.16 The case-law is replete with expression of judicial opinion defining socialism. The main emphasis is on the establishment of an egalitarian social order through rule of law.

The aim of social justice is to attain a substantial degree of social, economic and political equality. Social justice is a device to mitigate the suffering of the poor, weak, Tribals and the deprived sections of the society and to elevate them so that they can live with dignity. In course of time, the Courts have raised social and economic justice to the high level of a Fundamental Right.22 While upholding the Constitutionality of the amendment to Art. 15 by inserting Art. 15(5), the Supreme Court in Ashoka Kumar Thakur v.
